questions.text: Which of the following works by disrupting the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Lysol works by disrupting the cell membrane. 

Lysol is a phenol compound, which is obtained by distillation of coal tar. Phenols cause cell membrane damage and inactivate membrane-bound oxidases and dehydrogenases. This causes lysis and release of cell contents. Low concentrations of phenol can precipitate proteins. They are not inactivated by organic matter and are thus useful disinfectants. 

The mechnisms of action of other disinfecting agents are:

  1. DNA damage
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Ultraviolet light
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • DNA reactive chemicals like acriflavin. 
  2. Protein modification
    • Alcohol
    • Chlorine
    • Iodine
    • Heavy metals (e.g. thiomersal)
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
    • Ethylene oxide
    • Acids and alkalis

questions.text: Muscle cannot release glucose from glycogen because of the deficiency of which of the following  enzymes?
questions.solution:
Muscles cannot release glucose into the blood due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.

Glucose-6-phosphatase is present in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes. Hence, hepatocytes can convert glucose-6-phosphate into glucose and release glycogen-derived glucose into the blood in order to maintain blood glucose levels stable, until gluconeogenesis kicks in. 

However, myocytes lack the enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase. As a result, glucose-6-phosphate cannot be dephosphorylated and released into the blood. Muscle glycogen provides a readily available source of glucose-1-phosphate for glycolysis within the muscle itself.

Defects in the enzyme or glucose-6-phosphate transporter (GLUT 7) can cause type I glycogen storage disease.

questions.text: A mother brought her 12-day old baby to the OPD due to the rash shown in the picture for the last 5 days. The mother says the rash gets worse in the sun. The infant was born at home and she never had a prenatal check-up. She herself has a history of joint pains and a facial rash which she says is "no big deal". On examination, Vitals are normal for the baby. A subsequent ECG shows P wave rate 120/min and R wave rate at 70/min with no relation between the two. Which of the following antibodies will be used to diagnose this baby's condition?
questions.solution:
The baby has raccoon eyes (periorbital rash) with complete heart block (P-R dissociation) suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE). Anti-Ro antibodies are used to diagnose neonatal lupus. 

Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus(NLE):

NLE is not an autoimmune condition. It occurs when maternal autoantibodies enter the fetal circulation (passive transfer). The antibodies responsible for this condition are anti-Ro antibody (anti-SSA) and anti-La antibody (anti-SSB).

The periorbital rash typically appears within 6 weeks of life and lasts 3-4 months. However, it can be present at birth. Infants may also have cytopenias and hepatitis, but the most feared complication is congenital heart block. Cardiomyopathy is seen in the most severe cases. The noncardiac manifestations of neonatal lupus are usually reversible, whereas congenital heart block is permanent. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age.

Fluorinated corticosteroids seem to improve cases of hydrops. Significant conduction system abnormalities after birth are treated with cardiac pacing and occasionally intravenous immunoglobulin and steroids, while severe cardiomyopathy may require cardiac transplantation. Transient, noncardiac manifestations are conservatively managed, with topical steroids used occasionally to treat the rash. 

Other options:

Anti-Jo antibodies are a type of myositis-specific antibodies. These are not related to neonatal lupus. 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for SLE (Systemic Lupus erythematosus).

Anti-histone antibodies are present in Drug-induced SLE.

Note:

SS in SSA and SSB stands for Sjögren's syndrome-related. Anti-SSA and anti SSB are antinuclear antibodies and are mainly found in patients with SLE and Sjögren's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of RNA polymerase II?
questions.solution:
Synthesis of rRNA is not a function of RNA polymerase II. This is done by RNA polymerase I

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

questions.text: Which of the following statins has the longest half life?
questions.solution: Rosuvastatin has the longest half-life (around 19 hours) among the statins.

questions.text:
Vasculitis that involves capillaries is______.
A. Buerger disease
B. Behcet disease
C. Leucocytoclastic vasculitis
D. Churg-Strauss syndrome
questions.solution:
Vasculitis affecting the capillaries are leukocytoclastic vasculitis, Behcet disease, and Churg–Strauss syndrome.

*Note - MICROSCOPIC POLYANGITIS (MPA) also affects small vessels such as capillaries, venules and  arterioles.

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

questions.text: How many molecules of acetyl-CoA are produced in β- oxidation of palmitic acid?
questions.solution:
In the β-oxidation of palmitic acid (C16), 8 molecules of acetyl-CoA are produced.

In the beta-oxidation pathway, two carbons at a time are cleaved from acyl-CoA molecules between alpha(2) and beta(3) carbons, starting at the carboxyl end. The two-carbon units formed are called acetyl-CoA.

Thus, in palmitic acid (C16), 7 cycles of β-oxidation take place, releasing 8 acetyl CoA molecules. In the first 6 cycles, 6 acetyl CoA molecules are released. In the 7th cycle, 2 acetyl CoA molecules are released.

questions.text: The specimen obtained by performing incision and drainage of a breast abscess was sent for culture on nutrient agar.  An image of the culture plate is given below. Microscopy of the isolated organism revealed gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this organism?

choices.text: Golden yellow pigmentation  is due to β-carotene
Pigment production is enhanced by adding milk to culture media
Confluent growth presents a characteristic  'oil-paint appearance'

questions.solution:
Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters that produce golden-yellow pigment on nutrient agar is suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C.

Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive coccus. On nutrient agar, its colonies are large (2-4 mm in diameter), convex, smooth, shiny, opaque and easily emulsifiable. The colonies appear golden yellow due to the presence of staphyloxanthin (carotenoid). Pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C and in aerobic conditions. It is enhanced when 1% glycerol or milk is incorporated in the medium.

On a nutrient agar slope, there is confluent growth of Staphylococcus, which appears as a characteristic oil-paint appearance.

questions.text:
Which of the following must be avoided by a patient with tubal pregnancy on methotrexate?
  1. Sunlight exposure
  2. Sexual intercourse
  3. Dairy products
  4. NSAIDs
  5. Azithromycin
questions.solution:
Sunlight exposure, sexual intercourse and NSAIDs must be avoided when patients are on methotrexate therapy.

The following should be avoided when methotrexate therapy has been initiated for the treatment of ectopic gestation:

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs - can cause reduced renal blood flow and delay drug excretion
  • Alcohol - can predispose to concurrent hepatic enzyme elevation
  • Sunlight - may provoke methotrexate-related dermatitis
  • Sexual intercourse - can rupture the ectopic pregnancy
  • Phenytoin, tetracyclines, salicylates, and sulfonamides - can increase serum methotrexate levels

questions.text: In individuals exposed to HIV, within how many hours should prophylaxis be initiated?
questions.solution: Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should ideally be initiated within 72 hours. It is recommended that it be started as even as early as < 2 hours.

questions.text: You are observing your senior resident press a patient’s skin lesion with a pinhead. The patient flinches in pain. Name the finding.
questions.solution:
Ollendorff probe sign or Buschke-Ollendorff sign refers to the deep dermal tenderness elicited by pressing the papular lesions of secondary syphilis with a pinhead. 

Option A: Buschke-Lowenstein tumor is another name for giant condyloma acuminatum or verrucous carcinoma. It is a malignant growth tumor associated with HPV infection. It is not a clinical sign.

Option B: Gorlin’s sign is the ability to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of the tongue as seen below. It is seen in patients with Ehler-Danlos syndrome.

Option C: Love’s sign refers to the exact localization of tenderness using a pinhead in a glomus tumor.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a false positive hydrostatic test in fetus seen?
questions.solution:
The hydrostatic test is falsely positive in the case of putrefied fetus.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth. If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is stillborn.

An unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float, giving a false positive test, due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction. 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of nasal obstruction and frequent nose bleeds. CT scan shows Holman-Miller sign. You suspect a benign tumour of the nasopharynx. What is its most common site of origin?

choices.text: Anterior wall of the sphenoid bone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumour grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus- Holman-Miller sign.

questions.text:
Endometriosis is seen in
  1. Peritoneum
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Pancreas
  5. Brain
questions.solution:
Endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Note: Endometriosis is seen rarely in the brain and pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following is a MAO-B inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Selegiline, rasagiline and safinamide are MAO-B inhibitors indicated in Parkinson’s disease.

Note: Safinamide is a newer MAO-B inhibitor approved for use in parkinsons disease in combination with levodopa and carbidopa (option b).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about cadaveric rigidity in contrast to cadaveric spasm?
  1. It is due to the depletion of ATP
  2. Muscles respond to electrical stimuli
  3. It happens instantaneously after death
  4. It is an antemortem phenomenon
  5. It indicates time since death
questions.solution:
Cadaveric rigidity is also known as rigor mortis. It is due to the depletion of ATP and indicates time since death. Muscle stiffening is not marked and can be overcome by moderate force. The rigor starts occurring 1-2 hours after death (postmortem nature) and muscles do not respond to electrical stimuli.

Cadaveric spasm / instantaneous rigor/ cataleptic rigidity/ death clutch is a phenomenon where a group of muscles in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death until molecular death occurs.

Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem phenomenon and occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like:

  • In cases of excitement, fear, severe pain
  • Exhaustion at the time of death
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Injury to the nervous system
  • Drowning
  • Strychnine poisoning

Examples:

  • In case of drowning, weeds and grass caught in hand during struggle remain firmly grasped even after death. This indicates that the person was alive when entering the water
  • In case of suicides, weapons remain firmly grasped in the hand

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

Trait Cadaveric rigidity Cadaveric spasm
Production Freezing and exposure to a temperature above 650C will produce rigor Cannot be produced by any method after death
Mechanism Reduction of ATP Not clear
Predisposing factors Nil Sudden death, excitement, fear, etc
Time of onset 1 – 2 hours after death Instantaneous
Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline
Medicolegal importance Indicates the time of death Indicates manner of death

questions.text: A newborn baby has rashes over the face as shown below, microcephaly, bilateral cataracts, and sensory neural hearing loss. What is the most common type of cataract seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. The type of cataract seen in this condition is a nuclear pearly cataract. 

Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs due to the transplacental transmission of the virus from an infected mother to the fetus. The transmissibility is highest in the first trimester (<11 weeks).

Affected babies present with a triad of:

  • Sensorineural deafness
  • Cataracts- nuclear pearly cataracts
  • Congenital heart disease- the most common is the patent ductus arteriosus.

Other important features are rashes over the body, salt and pepper retinopathy, and microcephaly. Some babies may develop meningoencephalitis following CRS.

It is diagnosed by the presence of IgM antibodies against rubella in the cord or neonatal blood. Administration of MMR vaccine in prepubertal and women who are about to get married can prevent the disease.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

Related Pearl: Ocular manifestation in infections

questions.text: A patient in low output cardiogenic shock is being treated with dobutamine. Which of the following is true about the drug?

choices.text: Acts on D1 and D2 receptors
Has no effect on coronary circulation

questions.solution:
Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance minimally.

Clinically, dobutamine increases cardiac output by selectively increasing myocardial contractility and promotes coronary vasodilation. This is associated with a mild decrease in total peripheral vascular resistance, which is mediated by the reflex withdrawal of sympathetic tone to the vasculature.

Dobutamine has a t1/2 of 2 minutes. It resembles dopamine but no action is seen on dopamine receptors.

Renal circulation is variably affected depending upon the sympathetic tone of the patient.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is rushed to the emergency department because of an episode of fits associated with uprolling of eyes and high fever. Kernig’s sign is negative and there are no post-ictal neurological deficits. There is a history of a similar episode when the child had a fever due to gastroenteritis. Which of the following is false regarding this type of seizures?

choices.text: Likelihood of developing epilepsy is low
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions
Absence of having a developmental delay

questions.solution:
This is a probable case of febrile seizures due to the presence of high fever, no post-ictal deficits and a negative Kernig's sign ruling out meningitis. Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure, as the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly.

Febrile seizures are seizures that-

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails or in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism implicated in the condition depicted below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows rough finger-like growth over the vulva which is suggestive of condyloma acuminata. It is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV-6 > HPV-11).

It is also called genital/venereal warts and has high infectivity. It is acquired most commonly after sexual contact but may also occur non-sexually.

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are both the first-line drugs used in the treatment of genital warts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Trichinella cyst is false?

choices.text: Cyst is formed by the tissue reaction around the encapsulated larvae
Larvae inside the cysts remain infective for long years, become calcified and die
A muscle cell carrying larva of T. spiralis is called as a nurse cell
Cyst develop in muscles rich in glycogen

questions.solution:
The Trichinella cysts develop in muscles which are relatively poor in glycogen and provide a hypoxic environment.

A muscle cell carrying larva of T. spiralis is called as a nurse cell.

Trichinella cyst:

  • Cysts are ovoid 400µm by 250µm in size
  • The cyst is formed by the tissue reaction around the encapsulated larvae.
  • Cyst develops preferentially in muscles which have relatively poor glycogen and provide hypoxic environment. E.g., Diaphragm, biceps, muscles of jaw, extra ocular muscles, neck and lower back, which are constantly active, are the ones mostly affected.
  • Cysts are abundant near the sites of attachment of muscles to tendons and bones than in other parts.
  • Larvae remains infective inside the cyst for years and eventually, most become calcified and die.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be present in patients with ARDS?
questions.solution:
Increased left atrial pressure is not likely to be present in ARDS.

ARDS is characterized by

  • PCWP of ≤18 mmHg with normal LA pressure
  • Decreased pulmonary compliance
  • Increased pulmonary artery pressure
  • Severe hypoxemia

questions.text: What is the most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. 

Myelophthisic anaemia describes a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. Causes include:

  • Metastatic cancer
  • Granulomatous diseases
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasms. 

This leads to the release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms into peripheral blood (leukoerythroblastosis) and tear-drop shaped red cells. 

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with teardrop cells.

questions.text: In pregnant women who are administered general anaesthesia, which of the following is the most common cause for mortality?
questions.solution:
Pregnant women who undergo general anaesthesia are at increased risk of mortality from pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents. 

Other risk factors include failed intubation of the trachea and inadequate ventilation. General anaesthesia has a 1.7 times greater risk of maternal morbidity and mortality than regional anaesthesia. Maternal mortality associated with aspiration is 5-15%.

Mendelson's syndrome is chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonitis caused by aspiration during anaesthesia, especially during pregnancy.

questions.text: What process is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3?

choices.text: Movement of Na+ into the cell
Movement of Na+ out of the cell
Movement of K+ into the cell
Movement of K+ out of the cell

questions.solution:
The graph depicts action potential. The movement of Na+ into the cell is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3.

Once the membrane is depolarized to the threshold, local potential, the upstroke of the nerve action potential is caused by the opening of the Na+ channels. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. When the Na+ channels open, Na+ moves into the cell down its electrochemical gradient, driving the membrane potential toward the Na+ equilibrium potential.

The process responsible for repolarization is the opening of K+. The K+ permeability becomes very high and drives the membrane potential toward the K+equilibrium potential by the flow of K+ out of the cell.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.

The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³.

It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen.

  • Total blood count:
    • Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. 
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections.
    • 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells.
  • Peripheral smear:
    • Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
    • Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears.
    • Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.
    • Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both)
  • Lymph node biopsy:
    • Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates
    • Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL.

The chromosomal defects:

  • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
  • Deletion of 11q
  • Trisomy 12q
  • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).

questions.text: A patient comes to you with hair loss as shown below. How will you classify its severity?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows female pattern hair loss with frontoparietal thinning and maintenance of the frontal hairline. Female pattern hair loss staging is done using the Ludwig staging.

 

Option B: Hamilton Norwood staging is used for male pattern hair loss (MPHL). 

Option C: Tanner staging is used to assess sexual maturity. 

Option D: Batts-Ludwig staging is used for staging chronic hepatitis.

questions.text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of seeing double after having suffered a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture.

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence. 
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. 
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. 
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. 
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. 
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:

questions.text: A pregnant lady comes for a routine antenatal checkup during the first trimester. USG examination reveals the following finding. Identify the type of twins in this patient.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of dichorionic, diamniotic twins. The image shows two separate amniotic cavities (diamniotic) and lambda sign (dichorionic). 

In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign. The following image shows the lambda/twin peak.

Dichorial, diamniotic twins can occur in 2 instances: 

  • Dizygotic twins: The two fertilized ova get implanted at two separate sites and develop separate chorion and two separate amniotic cavities
  • Monozygotic twins: With early blastomere separation (up to 3rd day after fertilization), the two embryos formed will have separate chorionic and amniotic sacs, similar to dizygotic twins.

questions.text: A Bennett fracture is difficult to maintain in a reduced state due to the pull of ________.
questions.solution:
Bennett's fracture is difficult to maintain in a reduced state due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon on the shaft of the first metacarpal. 

The small fractured fragment remains in contact with the trapezium but the rest of the metacarpal shaft is pulled proximally by the abductor pollicis longus tendon that is attached to its base.

In contrast, the comminuted fracture line of Rolando's fracture prevents the pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon from being exerted on the metacarpal shaft.

questions.text: Mayer waves are due to ____.

choices.text: Variation of arterial pressure during each systole.
Variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure
Variation of arterial pressure with changes in respiration.
Variation of arterial pressure with postural change.

questions.solution:
Mayer waves are due to the variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure.

The most important mechanisms are as follows:

I: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor reflex:

High pressure excites the baroreceptors -->inhibits sympathetic nervous system and lowers the pressure -->The decreased pressure, in turn, reduces the baroreceptor stimulation -->elevating the pressure to a high value (the response is not instantaneous, it is delayed until a few seconds later). This high pressure then initiates another cycle, and the oscillation continues.

II: Oscillation of the CNS Ischemic Response:

The cerebrospinal fluid pressure is raised to 160 mm Hg --> causes compression of cerebral blood vessels --> cerebral ischemia--> CNS ischemic pressure response raises the arterial pressure up to 200mm Hg -->the brain ischemia is relieved and the sympathetic nervous system becomes inactive -->the arterial pressure falls rapidly back to a much lower value, causing brain ischemia once again -->initiates another rise in pressure. This chain of events repeats itself cyclically as long as the cerebrospinal fluid pressure remains elevated.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement from the following.

choices.text: Children with pica are at increased risk of megaloblastic anemia
Breath-holding spells are associated with hypertonia
Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension
Bedwetting after a period of 3 months of dryness at night is called secondary enuresis

questions.solution:
Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension. It is a self-limiting habit disorder, usually seen between 6 months to 2 years.

Option A: Pica is persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances for at least 1 month. It hampers the development of the child and requires clinical attention. Children with pica are at an increased risk of lead poisoning, iron-deficiency anemia, and parasitic infections.

Option B: Breath-holding spells: It is preceded by a provocative event such as anger. Crying stops at full expiration. Child may have apnoea, cyanosis, pallor, hypotonia, or even loss of consciousness, and generalized tonic–clonic seizure (GTCS). Subtypes include cyanotic, pallid, and mixed episodes. Seizures and cardiac causes should be ruled out. Parents should be reassured that breath-holding spells are self-limiting.

Option D: Enuresis:

  • When the child has never been dry, it is called primary enuresis.
  • When the bedwetting starts after a minimum period of six months of dryness at night, it is termed as secondary enuresis.
  • Nocturnal enuresis is caused due to maturational delay. In a normal individual, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels usually peak between 4 am and 8 am. This circadian rhythm is impaired in nocturnal enuresis, leading to bedwetting.
  • Treatment - Behavioural therapy with positive reinforcement, bladder alarms, and desmopressin reserved for cases resistant to behavioural therapy.

questions.text: Histopathology of a tissue sample from a patient with leprosy is shown below. Which form of the disease is this patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a grenz zone or Band of Unna, which is a band of uninvolved papillary dermis that does not contain granulomas or inflammatory infiltrate. It is absent in tuberculoid leprosy.

The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy, as there are scarce granulomas to fill up the space. It is also seen in the borderline spectrum.

In tuberculoid leprosy, dermal granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are seen. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.  

The grenz zone is also seen in granuloma faciale and B-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about skeletal traction?

choices.text: Applied with K wire/ Steinmann pin
Can be used only for short duration

questions.solution:
Skeletal traction is applied with K wire/ Steinmann pin. 

Differences between skeletal and skin traction are 

  Skin traction Skeletal traction
Required for Moderate force Severe force
Age Children  Adults
Applied with  Adhesive plaster K wire/Steinmann pin
Common site Below knee Upper tibial pin traction
Applied  On skin Through bone
Weight 3-4 kg Upto 20 kg
Duration Short Long

questions.text: A patient has the catheter shown below inserted for draining a large liver abscess. All of the following statements are true except:

choices.text: It is a self retaining catheter
It may be introduced into the urethra to relieve bladder retention
It can be placed percutaneously through an existing nephrostomy

questions.solution:
A Malecot catheter is never introduced per-urethrally.

It is a self-retaining catheter with an umbrella or flower tip. It contains sulfur, hence is radio-opaque. It can be sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Pyonephrosis
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystotomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of pancreas
  • Amoebic liver abscess
  • Gastrostomy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma?

choices.text: Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for PAX 5
It  is uncommonly associated with Epstein Barr Virus
Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for CD45

questions.solution:
Reed–Sternberg cells in nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) are negative for CD45. It is the most common variant.

These are characterized by the presence of lacunar variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the deposition of collagen bands. These bands divide involved lymph nodes into circumscribed nodules.

The Reed-Sternberg cells are found in a polymorphous background of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are often uncommon.

The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for PAX5 (a B-cell transcription factor), CD15, and CD30, and negative for other B-cell markers, T-cell markers, and CD45 (leukocyte common antigen). This subtype is uncommonly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Involvement of the spleen, liver, bone marrow and other organs and tissues can occur later in the disease. 

The prognosis is excellent.

questions.text:
Patients with which of the following conditions are likely to have calcified lesions on CT head?
  1. Craniopharyngioma
  2. Ependymoma
  3. Chordoma
  4. Glioblastoma multiforme
  5. Oligodendroglioma
questions.solution:
Craniopharyngiomas, ependymomas, oligodendrogliomas, and chordomas are associated with calcification.

Commonly calcified lesions are:

  • Oligodendrogliomas (90%)
  • Choroid plexus tumours
  • Ependymoma
  • Central neurocytoma
  • Meningioma
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Teratoma
  • Chordoma

Commonly hemorrhagic lesions include:

  • Glioblastoma multiforme (grade 4 glioma)
  • Oligodendroglioma
  • Metastases: Melanoma, lung, and breast

questions.text: Heymann nephritis is due to antibodies against which antigen?

choices.text: α3 chain of type IV collagen

questions.solution:
Heymann nephritis is due to antibodies against antigen megalin present in epithelial cell foot processes.

Heymann nephritis rat model is the well-studied experimental counterpart of membranous nephropathy, from which much of the underlying pathophysiology of glomerular immune complex-mediated diseases has been deduced.

It is induced by immunizing rats with an antigen, now known to be megalin.

Other options:

  • M type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) is the antigen involved in most cases of primary membranous nephropathy.
  • NC1 domain of α3 chain of type IV collagen is the antigen responsible for anti-GBM antibody-induced glomerulonephritis and Good pasture syndrome.

questions.text: A patient has chronic cough with occasional blood in the sputum. He has a history of significant weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following media cannot be used to culture the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include:

  • Solid- Loeffler's medium is a serum-containing solid medium used for the culture of M. tuberculosis. Other solid media used include Lowenstein- Jensen medium, Dorset medium, Tarshis medium, and Pawlowsky's medium.
  • Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and in sensitivity testing.  Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium.
  • Automated culture methods: 
    • BACTEC 460- uses radioisotopes for detection
    • BacT alert- colorimetric method of detection
    • BACTEC MGIT- fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: The given instrument can be used to measure all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of the kata thermometer. It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently, it is only used to measure low air velocities.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Schwannomas are associated with chromosome_________.
questions.solution:
Schwannomas are associated with chromosome 22.

Schwannoma:

  • Benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves.
  • Schwannomas are a component of NF2, and sporadic schwannomas are commonly associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22.
  • Loss of expression of the NF2 gene product merlin is a consistent finding in all schwannomas.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is unlikely to be seen in the radiograph of a patient suspected to have pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails (given in the image below).

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Rigler's sign, telltale triangle sign, falciform ligament sign are the radiological findings seen in a supine abdominal x-ray.

Signs of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs
    • Double-wall sign / Rigler's sign / bas-relief sign - air is seen on both sides of the bowel wall
    • Telltale triangle sign / triangle sign
  • Peritoneal ligament-related signs
    • Football sign - air outlines the confines of the peritoneal cavity
    • Falciform ligament sign - air outlines the falciform ligament
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign / inverted "V" sign - air outlines the lateral umbilical ligament
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Cupola sign - air outlines the median subphrenic space
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Morison's pouch sign / Doge cap sign
    • Periportal free gas sign.

The image given below is an abdominal radiograph showing Rigler's sign in pneumoperitoneum. Here both the inner and the outer walls of the bowel are visible.

The below image is a supine abdominal radiograph is showing the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow). This is known as the falciform ligament sign.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding propofol?
questions.solution:
Propofol has antipruritic properties. It can also relieve cholestatic pruritus and may be as effective as naloxone in treating pruritus induced by spinal opiates.

Option A: Propofol produces a 25% to 40% reduction in systolic blood pressure following injection.

Option C: Propofol is formulated as a lipid emulsion that causes pain during injection. This can be decreased by using a large vein, avoiding veins in the dorsum of the hand, prior injection of lidocaine or by mixing lidocaine with propofol prior to injection (2 mL of 1% lidocaine in 18 mL propofol).

Option D: Propofol produces maximum inhibition of airway reflexes and can facilitate intubation, endoscopy, or laryngeal mask placement without neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about eosinophilic esophagitis?

choices.text: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
Treatment of choice is systemic steroids
May be associated with food products like cow’s milk and soy products

questions.solution:
Treatment of choice are proton pump inhibitors, which when started as primary therapy is effective in 30 - 50 % of affected individuals. 
Additionally, elimination of allergenic proteins from diet as it is is associated with atopy and exposure to food allergens like cow’s milk and soy products.
Swallowed topical steroids are used as well.

Immunocompromised patients are treated with acyclovir, famciclovir or valacyclovir.

Factors Eosinophilic esophagitis GERD
Dominant symptoms Dysphagia Heartburn and regurgitation
Food impaction Common Uncommon
Gender Male predominance Male = female
Age Children, young adults Middle age
Esophageal findings on endoscopy
  • Edema
  • Multiple stacked rings (feline esophagus) and longitudinal furrows
  • Punctate exudates
  • Strictures and narrow-caliber esophagus
  • Crepe-paper esophagus
Normal findings in <10% patients
  • Erosions and ulcers
  • Strictures
  • Barrett's esophagus and adenocarcinoma
Normal findings on endoscopy in majority of patients
Ambulatory pH testing Negative or positive Positive
Histology ≥15 eosinophils/hpf <7 eosinophils/hpf
Etiology Atopic or immune-mediated, acid reflux is not prominent Acid reflux
Primary treatment

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs)

Elimination of allergens in diet

Steroids (topical)

 

Antacids

H2 receptor blockers

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs)

FDA recently approved Dupilumab, a monocloncal antibody to treat eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) in adults and pediatric patients 12 years & older

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic CT appearance seen in patients with acute subdural hematoma?
questions.solution:
A crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines on axial CT is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are:

  • Typically unilateral
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain
  • Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections
  • Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT
  • Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT

A lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion that does not cross suture lines on axial CT is suggestive of an epidural hemorrhage.

The image given below shows a subdural hematoma with a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion on CT:

 

The image given below is that of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage seen on CT:

 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following is not a continuous variable?

choices.text: Blood glucose value of a diabetic patient
Number of visits to the hospital in a year

questions.solution:
The number of visits to the hospital in a year is a discrete variable. The only values it can take are whole numbers and none in between. For example, you can’t visit the hospital 2.5 times.

Blood glucose value, mid-arm circumference and birth weight are continuous variables. They can have any value within a limit or a range.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: A patient is recovering from a spinal shock after a fall from height. Which of the following is the first reflex that you will expect to reappear in him?
questions.solution:
Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.

It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pulling the Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.

Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function (motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact, direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result in hemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic function).

The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowly transitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather than simultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by the conus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site involved in discoid lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Discoid lupus erythematosus is a benign inflammatory disorder of the skin, most frequently involving the face and scalp. 

It is characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size, which heal with atrophy, scarring, and pigmentary changes. The circumscribed or discoid form is the most frequent type of disease and occurs particularly on the cheeks, bridge of the nose, ears, side of the neck, and scalp.

The image below shows a localized discoid lupus erythematosus of the scalp with follicular plugging.

questions.text: You are assisting in a modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following steps will not be done by the operating surgeon during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss).

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important structure contributing to fracture healing?
questions.solution:
The most important structure contributing to fracture healing is periosteum.

The periosteum is an excellent source of local mesenchymal stem cells that can enhance bone repair.

This should be taken into account when considering direct contact plates that press against the periosteum, potentially damaging the vascular supply and leading to periosteal necrosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman diagnosed with uterine prolapse, now presented with dyspareunia and fecal incontinence. After manually reducing the prolapse, a peristaltic bulge is seen in the posterior vaginal wall. What is the preferred method of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an enterocele associated with fecal incontinence. It is preferably repaired using an abdominal approach like Moschcowitz repair.

An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginal septum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present with the following clinical features:

  • Fecal incontinence
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Constipation/diarrhea
  • Mass descending PV
  • Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort
  • A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall:
    • Upper 1/3rd - enterocele
    • Lower 2/3rd - rectocele
  • Peristalsis may be observed in the bulge 

Enterocele repair is done via the following methods:

  • Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall's culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posterior peritoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated. 
  • Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. It includes:
    • Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures.
    • Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also be done transvaginally. 

Option B: Purandare's sling operation is abdominal wall cervicopexy for uterine prolapse. It is done for young nulliparous women.

Option D: Le Fort's repair is done in elderly patients with uterine prolapse, who are unfit for surgery.

Note: Enteroceles may be present along with uterine prolapse. Failure to identify and repair it during vaginal hysterectomy can lead to vault prolapse.

Related Pearl: Management of Vaginal prolapse

questions.text: A 35-year-old male whose BMI is 32 is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat diabetes but not cause weight loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pioglitazone is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus and can cause edema and weight gain, rather than weight loss. 

Thiazolidinediones include drugs like pioglitazone and rosiglitazone and act by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors-gamma (PPAR-γ). These receptors are expressed predominantly in adipose tissues and cause adipocyte differentiation. It also facilitates the uptake of fatty acids and lipid stores to adipose tissues.

They produce anti-glycemic action by increasing tissue sensitivity to insulin. They increase insulin-mediated glucose uptake in skeletal muscle. They also reduce hepatic glucose production and increase hepatic glucose uptake. These drugs require the presence of insulin for their action as anti-diabetic agents and hence cannot be used to treat type-1 diabetes mellitus.

These drugs are contraindicated in patients with moderate-to-severe heart failure and liver failure. They must be used with caution in patients with osteoporosis.

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist that provides glycemic control and also facilitates weight loss.

Options B: Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor that also causes weight loss.

Option D: Metformin is a biguanide and is associated with weight loss, especially in obese patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old normotensive patient with dyslipidemia is undergoing a regular check-up. He is at an increased risk of developing all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Dyslipidemia is not a direct risk factor for deep vein thrombosis.

Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for atherosclerosis and its complications, including abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). AAA can also be associated with smaller aneurysms of the iliac arteries. Patients with AAA are also likely to have atherosclerotic lesions in other vascular beds that may lead to ischemic heart disease or stroke.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child abruptly developed symptoms suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder and Tourette syndrome. PANDAS, a pediatric neuropsychiatric disorder, is suspected. Which of the following organisms is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
PANDAS is associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection.

PANDAS stands for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections.

The symptoms usually occur abruptly and can include the following:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
  • Tic disorder
  • Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (coprolalia and tics)

Additionally, children may become moody or irritable, experience anxiety attacks, and/or show separation anxiety. These symptoms are the result of an autoimmune process that leads to inflammation of the basal ganglia and the resultant disruption of cortical-striatal-thalamic axis functioning.

Features:

  • Prepubertal onset
  • Abrupt and episodic course
  • Neurological symptoms
  • Disorders associated: Tics, OCD
  • Associated with a recent history of sore throat

Note: Non-infectious manifestations of streptococcal infection:

  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PANDAS
  • Guttate psoriasis

questions.text: Which of the following hormones demonstrates the fluctuations depicted below?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, (Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM sleep)

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.text: In the doctor-patient relationship, which of the following is not a level of communication?
questions.solution:
Communication on a psychological plane is not a level of communication in a doctor-patient relationship.

For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication on the following levels:

  • Communication on an emotional plane: To build rapport, ensure openness and incite trust from the patient.
  • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs, his/her cultural factors that may influence health and disease and also for economic understanding of the patient.
  • Communication on an intellectual plane: To give adequate explanation for their conditions and help the patients develop insight into their ailments.

questions.text: While investigating a new disease, you are trying to establish the aetiological agent. Which of the following criterion is the most difficult to establish?
questions.solution:
Specificity is the most difficult criterion to establish in both chronic and acute diseases.

This is because a single factor or cause can give rise to more than one disease. Also, most diseases are multifactorial in origin with no possibility of demonstrating a one-to-one relationship which would indicate specificity.

Related Pearl: Hill's Criteria for Causal Association

  • It is also called Bradford Hill criteria.
  • It was established in 1965 by English epidemiologist, Sir Austin Bradford Hill.

Criteria

Brief Description

Temporality

Suspected cause precedes observed effect.

Strength

Larger the relative risk, the more likely it is causal.

Consistency

If the association is observed repeatedly under the same or various conditions, then more likely it is causation.

Specificity

When exposure is associated with a specific outcome only, then it is more likely to be causal.

Plausibility

A biologically plausible mechanism between cause and effect can be support for causation.

Coherence

A causal conclusion should not seriously conflict with the present substantive knowledge of the outcome.

Analogy

Other established cause-effect relationships may be used in analogies to support this causal relationship.

Gradient

It is called dose-response or response curve. It refers to the existence of an exposure-response relationship.

Experiment

To check if the condition can be or has been changed, weakened or prevented by experimental approach.

questions.text: In order to effectively prevent endemic goiter, what is the recommended iodine content in salt at the consumer level?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of iodine content in salt is 15 ppm at the consumer level and 30 ppm at the production level.

The iodization of salt is used as a prophylactic measure against endemic goiter. In India, the level of iodization is fixed under the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except that :

choices.text: It is a purely motor nerve
It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except option A as it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A boy with a BMI of 16.5 kg/m2 is admitted to the hospital for nutritional rehabilitation for restricting-type anorexia nervosa. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Self-induced vomiting is not a feature of restrictive-type anorexia nervosa. It is seen in the purging type.

Anorexia nervosa has been divided into two clinical subtypes:

Restricting-type Purging-type
Food intake is highly restricted (limited calories) Alternate attempts at rigorous dieting with intermittent binge or purge episodes
Compulsively overactive, with overuse athletic injuries Secondary compensation by self-induced vomiting or laxative abuse
Socially isolated, depressed, and diminished sexual interest Socially isolated, depressed, and diminished sexual interest

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year old man who suffered a head injury in an automobile accident. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne–Stokes breathing. In this case, the person breathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not for an additional interval. This pattern repeats itself about every minute.

It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heart failure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normal individuals.

This increased response occurs apparently due to the disruption of neural pathways that normally inhibit respiration. In such an individual, increased sensitivity to CO2 causes relative hyperventilation, lowering the arterial Pco2. During the resultant apnoea, the arterial Pco2 rises again to normal, but the respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2. Breathing ceases, and the cycle repeats.

questions.text: Dawn phenomenon is clinically suspected when a patient shows which of the following findings?

choices.text: Early morning hyperglycemia with hypoglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hyperglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with hyperglycemia at 3 am

questions.solution:
Dawn phenomenon refers to normal blood glucose levels at 3 am followed by early morning hyperglycemia.

This occurs due to an early morning surge in plasma growth hormone and cortisol levels, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. In normal individuals, this is countered by increased early morning insulin secretion. However, in diabetic patients, insulin secretion is disrupted which results in the unopposed action of growth hormone. Hence, there will be resulting hyperglycemia.

Related Pearl: Dawn Phenomenon and Somogyi Phenomenon

 

Dawn phenomenon

Somogyi phenomenon

Features

Early morning hyperglycaemia

Early morning hyperglycaemia

 

Normal blood glucose levels at 3 am

Hypoglycaemia at 3 am

Mechanism

Early morning surge in growth hormone and cortisol which causes hyperglycemia

Excessive night basal insulin dose > hypoglycemia in middle of night > triggers the release of counterregulatory hormones which causes hyperglycemia.

Treatment

Increase nighttime long-acting insulin dose

Decrease night time long-acting insulin dose

questions.text: Bubonocele is a type of _________.
questions.solution:
Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal.

Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal development.

Related Pearl: Types of indirect inguinal hernia

  • Bubonocele – Hernia limited to the inguinal canal.
  • Funicular – Hernia stops just above the testis.
  • Complete/scrotal – Hernia reaches bottom of scrotum.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with non-sense mutation?
questions.solution:
A non-sense mutation is seen in β0 thalassemia.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations: These involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases. It leads to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. These mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein. Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:
    • Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.
    • Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one.
  2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon.

For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

Option B: α-thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of α-globin chains.

Option C: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation. It occurs due to the replacement of the 6th glutamic acid by valine in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11. 

Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), an active form of pyridoxine serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions.

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is a coenzyme for enzymes involved in the following:

  • Transamination
  • Decarboxylation
  • Glycogenolysis: Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Transsulfuration reaction: Cystathionine β-synthase and cystathionase
  • Heme synthesis: ALA synthase (deficiency causes microcytic hypochromic anemia)
  • Tryptophan metabolism: Kynureninase (deficiency causes pellagra-like symptoms)

Note: Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) serves as a coenzyme in many amino acid metabolisms, so its RDA mainly depends on daily protein intake.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for predicting prognosis in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The increased levels of serum beta 2 microglobulins in patients with multiple myeloma have been associated with a poor prognosis.

Beta-2 microglobulin is a low-molecular-weight protein found on the surface of all nucleated cells. It is the light chain of the HLA histocompatibility complex.

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Myeloma

Poor prognosis

Good prognosis

t(4;14), MAF translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20), del(17p), aneuploidy, hypodiploidy

Hyperdiploid, t(11;14), t(6;14), cyclin D1 or D3 positive

Elevated beta-2 microglobulin, lactate dehydrogenase, C- reactive protein, plasma-cell proliferation, or bone marrow infiltration

Plasmablastic morphology

Abnormalities by conventional cytogenetics

Plasma labelling index >3%

Serum creatinine level >2mg/dL

Bone marrow biopsy: Diffuse and prominent angiogenesis

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-metabolites act as an antifungal agent?
questions.solution:
Flucytosine is an anti-metabolite that acts as an antifungal agent.

Fungal cytosine deaminase converts flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. 5-fluorouracil is further converted into metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase, an enzyme that is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as it lacks cytosine deaminase enzyme.

Flucytosine has clinically useful activity (3C) against

  • Cryptococcus
  • Candida albicans
  • Chromoblastomycosis

The current pharmacological utility of flucytosine is in the treatment of HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis (in combination with amphotericin B) and in chromoblastomycosis (in combination with itraconazole).

Other options:

Option A - Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits the enzymes dihydrofolate reductase and thymidylate synthase. It impairs de novo synthesis of purine nucleotides. It is used in the management of breast, head & neck, bladder cancers as well as lymphomas (primary central nervous system lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's).

Option B - Cladribine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) that inhibits the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase (impaired formation of deoxyribonucleotides) and integrates cladribine triphosphate into DNA (renders DNA non-functional). It is used to treat hairy cell leukemia, CLL, and lymphoma.

Option C - Clofarabine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) with action similar to that of cladribine. It is used in the treatment of pediatric ALL that is resistant to two prior chemotherapeutic treatments. It is also used in the treatment of pediatric and adult acute myeloid leukemias, and in myelodysplasia.
