questions.text: The correlation between variables A and B in a study was found to be 1.1. This indicates _____
questions.solution:
• The values of correlation coefficient (r) can be from -1 to +1.
  • The value of r being 1.1 most probably indicates a mistake.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with FGFR3 mutations?
questions.solution:
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene are not described in melanomas.

Fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR3) is a receptor tyrosine kinase.

Defects in the FGFR3 gene have been associated with several conditions:

  • Hypochondroplasia
  • Thanatophoric dwarfism
  • Seborrheic keratosis
  • Acanthosis nigricans
  • Bladder cancer
  • Craniosynostosis
  • Severe achondroplasia with developmental delay and acanthosis nigricans (SADDAN)

questions.text: A patient has presented to you with a burn wound as seen in the image below. With regards to Jackson's zones of tissue injury, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Area 2 is the most severely burned portion
The outer area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia
Vasodilation is seen in the area 3
Area 1 heals with minimal or no scarring

questions.solution:
Vasoconstriction (not vasodilation) is seen in red region or zone of stasis (marked zone 3).

Jackson zones of tissue injury following burns has three zones:

  • The zone of coagulation is the most severely burned portion and is typically in the center of the wound.
  • Peripheral to that is a zone of stasis, with variable degrees of vasoconstriction and resultant ischemia.
  • The last, outermost area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia, which will heal with minimal or no scarring and is most like a superficial or first-degree burn. It is characterized by vasodilation from inflammation surrounding the burn wound.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a one-month history of fever, fatigue, and non-productive cough. His chest X-ray is unremarkable, but HRCT is done and provided below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and HRCT showing tree-in-bud sign suggest endobronchial tuberculosis.

The tree-in-bud sign describes the CT appearance of multiple areas of centrilobular nodules with a linear branching pattern. The chest X-ray is usually normal in these patients.

CT showing a tree-in-bud sign with a linear branching pattern:

A tree-in-bud sign is also seen in a variety of other disorders like:

  • Bronchiolitis
  • Endobronchial tuberculosis
  • Atypical pneumonia
  • Bronchoalveolar carcinoma
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Bronchiectasis 
  • Cystic fibrosis 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with shortness of breath. He reports walking slower than his peers due to breathlessness. He has had two hospitalizations for similar complaints this year. His post-bronchodilator PFTs are FEV1/FVC < 0.55 and FEV1 55%.  Under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
This patient belongs to moderate COPD, group E category.

The severity of COPD assessed by the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

 

According to GOLD 2023 guidelines, COPD patients are classified into Group A, B, or E based on the severity of dyspnoea, frequency of exacerbations and hospitilization. Dyspnoea may be assessed using the modified MRC Dyspnoea scale or COPD Assessment Test (CAT score)

>=2 moderate exacerbations or >=1 leading to hospitalisation

Group E:
                         LABA+LAMA

consider LABA+LAMA+ICS* if blood eosinophil count >=300

 

0 or 1 moderate exacerbation (not leading to hospital admissions)

Group A: mMRC 0-1, CAT<10

                Bronchodilator

Group B: mMRC >=2, CAT >=10

          LABA + LAMA*

* single inhaler therapy maybe more convenient and effective than multiple inhalers

ICS - inhaled corticosteroids
LAMA - Long-acting Muscarinic Antagonists
LABA - Long-acting Beta Agonists

Modified MRC (mMRC) dyspnoea scale:

  • 0- Breathless only with strenuous exercise
  • 1- Breathless when hurrying on a level or walking up a hill
  • 2- Walks slower than peers or has to stop for breath when walking on level
  • 3- Stops for breath after walking about 100m or for a few minutes
  • 4- Breathless at rest

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic depicted from the following epidemic curve.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time. It occurs within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A young patient presented with symptoms of bronchial asthma and cromolyn sodium was prescribed. It should be administered by which of the following routes?
questions.solution:
Cromolyn sodium (Sodium cromoglycate) is administered through the inhalation route as an aerosol, through a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) in bronchial asthma.

Sodium cromoglycate is a mast cell stabilizer, which inhibits the degranulation of mast cells and restricts the release of inflammatory cytokines. It prevents bronchoconstriction but does not act as a direct bronchodilator and hence cannot be used once bronchoconstriction is established or during an asthmatic attack. 

It is not absorbed orally. It is administered through the inhalation route for the treatment of bronchial asthma. It can also be used in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis as a topical application.

The therapeutic benefit develops slowly over 2-4 weeks and lasts 1- 2 weeks after discontinuation of the drug. Its use has declined due to the widespread usage of inhaled corticosteroids.

Drugs used in the treatment of bronchial asthma

Bronchodilators

  • Beta-2 sympathomimetics: Salmeterol, Formoterol
  • Methylxanthines: Theophylline, Aminophylline
  • Anticholinergics: Ipratropium bromide, Tiotropium bromide

Anti-inflammatory

  • Corticosteroids (Inhalational): Beclomethasone, Budesonide, Fluticasone
  • Corticosteroids (Systemic): Prednisolone, Hydrocortisone
  • Mast cell stabilizers: Sodium cromoglycate, Ketotifen
  • Leukotriene antagonists: Montelukast, Zafirlukast
  • anti-IgE - Omalizumab

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and was prescribed ferrous fumarate tablets for 2 months. Which of the following channels help in the absorption of this iron taken orally into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
The channel that helps in the absorption of the iron into the enterocyte is divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Transport of iron across the brush border of the intestinal cells in the ferrous form is accomplished by DMT-1, also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp 2). 

The mechanism of iron absorption and transport - 

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. This iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1). 

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption. 

The following illustration shows the absorption of iron in the duodenum:

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of jaundice, loss of appetite, and weight loss for the past several months. After a full laboratory workup, a liver biopsy was performed which appeared as shown in the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows ground-glass hepatocytes which are a hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. 

These ground-glass hepatocytes are liver parenchymal cells that have an eosinophilic, granular, and glassy appearance on light microscopy. This appearance is due to the accumulation of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

Liver biopsy findings in viral hepatitis:

Virus Liver Biopsy Findings
Hepatitis A Hepatocyte swelling, monocyte infiltration, Councilman bodies
Hepatitis B  Ground glass appearance 
Hepatitis C  Lymphoid aggregates with a focal area of macrovesicular steatosis 
Hepatitis D Similar to HBV 
Hepatitis E Patchy necrosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA carboxylase is not a part of the fatty acid synthase complex.

The fatty acid synthase complex is a multienzyme polypeptide complex that synthesizes fatty acids from malonyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA. It is a dimer of two identical polypeptide monomers (homodimer). Each monomer contains six enzymes and the acyl carrier protein (ACP). ACP carries the intermediate products formed during fatty acid synthesis. The enzymes of the fatty acid synthase complex are as follows: 

1. Condensing unit:

  • Ketoacyl synthase
  • Malonyl/acetyl transacylase

2. Reduction unit:

  • Dehydratase
  • Enoyl reductase
  • Beta-ketoacyl reductase

3. Releasing unit:

  • Thioesterase

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.

Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.

Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years.

Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding broken heart syndrome is false?
questions.solution:
Broken heart syndrome or Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women.

Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy

  • Synonyms
    • Apical ballooning syndrome
    • Stress-induced cardiomyopathy
    • Broken heart syndrome

It is most common in postmenopausal women after sudden intense emotional or physical stress. The ECG changes can mimic an acute infarction. Coronary angiography may be needed to rule out acute coronary occlusion.

Treatment: No treatment has proven to be successful. Therefore symptomatic treatment is recommended.

  • Nitrates for pulmonary oedema
  • Intraaortic balloon pump for low output
  • Combined alpha+beta blockers if hemodynamically stable
  • Magnesium for arrhythmias related to QT prolongation

Due to the risk of ventricular rupture, anticoagulation is not undertaken.

The prognosis is good.

 

 

  • Ventriculography showing cardiac morphology in systole in a patient with takotsubo cardiomyopathy -global ventricular dilation with basal contraction
  • A takotsubo – a pot (tsubo) for catching octopus (tako).

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for an antenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the present pregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?

choices.text: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum

questions.solution:
In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictor of pre-eclampsia.

In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus, a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive of preeclampsia.

 Predictors of preeclampsia:

  • Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma
  • Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester)
  • Average MAP >90 mmHg

Predictors no longer used include:

  • Hemoconcentration
  • Elevated fibronectin
  • Increase in uric acid levels
  • Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h
  • Increased homocysteine levels
  • Roll-over test - screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-parametric test of significance?
questions.solution: Chi-square test is a non parametric test of significance. It is used for qualitative or nominal data.

questions.text: Pseudopapillitis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Pseudopapillitis is seen in hypermetropia.

In hypermetropia, fundus examination shows an optic disc that is small, has ill-defined margins, appears highly vascular, and simulates papillitis. However, as the optic disc is not swollen, as seen in papillitis, it is also called pseudopapillitis. A shiny retina is seen due to the greater brilliance of light reflections known as shot silk appearance.

A fundus image showing the same is given below.

In hypermetropia or long-sightedness, incident parallel rays of light come to a focus behind the light-sensitive retina, with the accommodation at rest. It may be axial, curvatural, index, positional and due to the absence of a crystalline lens.

Patients can be asymptomatic when the refractive error is small and corrected by the use of accommodation. Sustained accommodative efforts can give rise to symptoms such as tiredness of the eyes, headache, watering and mild photophobia. It may also lead to esotropic (convergent) squint in children. When the hypermetropia is high enough to not be corrected by accommodative efforts, patients experience defective vision.

On examination, the size of the eyeball may appear small and the cornea is slightly smaller. The anterior chamber is comparatively shallow. Other features on fundus examination include a shot silk appearance, where the entire retina may shine due to reflected light. It is usually treated by using convex lenses, which help focus the light rays on the retina.

Other options:

Option A: Myopia or short-sightedness is a condition where parallel rays of light come to a focus in front of the retina. Fundus examination shows an optic disc that is large, pale and has a crescent at the temporal edge, degenerative changes in retina, choroid, vitreous and presence of posterior staphyloma.

Option C: Aphakia refers to the absence of a crystalline lens. Fundus examination only shows a hypermetropic, small disc.

Option D: Presbyopia is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation, leading to a progressive fall in near vision.

Related Pearl: Grading of Hypermetropia

American Optometric Association (AOA) has defined three grades of hypermetropia:

  • Low hypermetropia: error of + 2D or less
  • Moderate hypermetropia: error from +2.25D to + 5D 
  • High hypermetropia: error is > + 5D

Related Pearl: Surgical treatment of hypermetropia

Cornea based procedures

Lens-based procedure

Thermal laser keratoplasty (TLK)

Refractive lens exchange

Hyperopic photorefractive keratotomy

 Phakic intraocular lens 

Conductive keratoplasty

questions.text: Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in all of the following conditions except

choices.text: Unlocalised primary tumour of the adrenals

questions.solution:
Unilateral adrenalectomy is done in adrenal incidentaloma with a size >4cm. 

Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in: 

  • Bilateral ACTH-independent disease
  • Ectopic ACTH-dependent Cushing’s Syndrome
  • Irresectable or unlocalized primary tumor 

Adrenalectomy is done as a surgical measure in severe hypercortisolism or Cushing's disease. The adrenalectomy can be unilateral or bilateral depending on whether the tumor autonomously secrete hormones that could have a detrimental effect on health or If the adrenal mass benign or malignant.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about erythema multiforme?

choices.text: Erythema multiforme major is the most common form
The lesions occur in crops and fade in 1-2 weeks
Photoaggravation of the lesions is seen
The distribution of target lesions is mainly acral

questions.solution:
Erythema multiforme minor (papular or simplex form) accounts for approximately 80% of cases and is the most common form.

Clinically erythema multiforme presents as macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic iris or ‘target lesions’, distributed preferentially on the distal extremities. Raised atypical target lesions having only two of the zones may also be seen and mucous membranes are rarely involved. Koebnerization accounts for some bizarre clinical distributions. 

Photoaggravation of erythema multiforme is well recognized.

The lesions appear in successive crops for a few days and fade in 1–2 weeks, sometimes leaving dusky discoloration.

The image given below shows mucosal involvement in erythema multiforme major

questions.text: What is the normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio?
questions.solution:
The normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4 to 1:6. 

Normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio implies that the volume occupied by the cytoplasm is 4 to 6 times greater than the volume occupied by the nucleus.

Abnormal nuclear morphologies that are seen in malignant cells:

  • Nuclei disproportionately large for the cell
  • Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular
  • Chromatin 
    • Coarsely clumped 
    • Hyperchromatic
  • Nucleoli are abnormally large

questions.text: Choose the wrong combination of the colour-coded STI kits among the given options.
questions.solution:
Kit 4 is blue in colour and is used for genital ulcers. These kits are given at Suraksha clinics.

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: In modified Liley's (Queenan) chart, which zone represents a severely affected fetus?
questions.solution:
A severely affected fetus is represented by zone 3.

Liley developed a chart of changing amniotic fluid bilirubin levels (delta OD450) and weeks of gestation. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm (ΔOD450).

However, middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PCV) is non-invasive and more accurate than optical density at 450 nm, hence Liley’s chart is no longer used in practice.

Liley’s chart has three zones as shown below, delineating the severity of rhesus disease.

  • Liley’s zone I (low zone) - mild disease. 
  • Liley’s zone II (mid zone) - fetal anemia.
  • Liley’s zone III (high zone) - severely affected fetus and fetal death is imminent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the presentation of renal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Flank pain is the most common presentation
It is more commonly associated with left sided varicoceles
It may be associated with pulsatile bony metastasis
Palpable abdominal mass is part of the classic triad seen in RCC

questions.solution:
The most common presentation in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is gross hematuria.

The classic triad (seen in <10% of cases) includes :

  • Gross hematuria 
  • Flank pain 
  • Palpable abdominal mass 

Rapidly developing varicoceles can be seen in patients with RCC. Varicocele is usually seen on the left side, as the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein at a sharp angle. On the right side, the gonadal vein opens into the much larger IVC.

Patients may also present with paraneoplastic syndromes. RCC can give rise to pulsatile bony metastases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding von Magnus phenomenon?

choices.text: Virus has low hemagglutination and high infectivity
von Magnus phenomenon is not seen in Influenza virus
Virus has high hemagglutination and high infectivity
Virus yield has high hemagglutination but low infectivity

questions.solution:
von Magnus phenomenon: If the yield of a virus has a high hemagglutinin titer, but low infectivity, then it is called von Magnus phenomenon.

  • It is seen when incomplete viruses are formed due to defective assembly during replication of viruses; hence, they may not be infective.
  • Generation of incomplete viruses is seen in large proportion, when cells are infected with a high dose of the influenza virus.
  • It was first observed by Preben von Magnus in influenza viruses, after the serial passage of virus in undiluted allantoic fluid in eggs.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady with rheumatic mitral stenosis becomes pregnant. At what point during her pregnancy would you be least concerned about her developing cardiac failure?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure in pregnancy is least likely to occur during 24 weeks, considering the given options.

The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor > 30 weeks > 22 weeks.

Maternal cardiac risk predictors: [Mnemonic: NOPE]

  N-NYHA class >2

  O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2  or aortic valve area <1.5 cm2, peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg)

  P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy

  E-Ejection fraction <40%

Scoring systems used to calculate risk are Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy (CARPREG) and ZAHARA scores.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about herd immunity?

choices.text: It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals
Vaccination allows the possibility of 100% herd immunity against a disease
It is affected by presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts
It doesn’t protect the individual in the case of tetanus

questions.solution:
It is not possible to achieve 100% herd immunity against a certain disease but studies have shown this is not necessary for disease control.

Herd structure is never constant. It is subject to constant variation because of new births, deaths and population mobility. An ongoing immunization programme will keep up the herd immunity at a very high level.

Related Pearl: Herd Immunity

  • Herd immunity is the level of protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunization.
  • It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of the population is immune to a certain disease.
  • Elements which contribute to herd immunity are:
    • Occurrence of clinical and sub-clinical infection in the herd
    • Immunization of the herd
    • Herd structure
  • The herd structure not only includes the primary species but also the presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts, vectors and other environmental/social factors that are related to disease spread.
  • It is not possible or necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population.
  • The proportion of immune individuals above which a disease may no longer spread is called herd immunity threshold.
  • This threshold depends upon the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.
  • Herd immunity is determined by serological surveys.
  • Herd immunity doesn’t offer protection against diseases like tetanus.

questions.text:
A patient has presented to your OPD with a sebaceous cyst on the scalp. You plan to excise it. Before making the first incision, you inject lidocaine around it. Which of the following effects does this drug have?
  1. Inhibition of Na channel
  2. Potentiation of K channel
  3. Interaction with NMDA receptors
  4. Inhibition of Ca channel
  5. Interference with oxidative phosphorylation
questions.solution:
Local anesthetics inhibit potassium channels. 

The effects of local anesthetics include:

  • Inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels
  • Blockade of potassium and calcium channels
  • Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)
  • Interaction with cholinergic or N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors
  • Interference with cellular metabolic processes (eg, oxidative phosphorylation, free fatty acid utilization)

However, the main action of local anesthetics is mediated by inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the actions of the muscle marked in the figure?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is the superior oblique.

Actions of the superior oblique:

  • Intorsion
  • Depression
  • Abduction

Longest extraocular muscle: Superior oblique

Shortest extraocular muscle: Inferior oblique

The primary action of a muscle is its major effect when the eye is in the primary position.

Subsidiary actions are the additional effects; these depend on the position of the eye.

The spiral of Tillaux is an imaginary line joining the insertions of the four recti and is an important anatomical landmark when performing surgery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was diagnosed with AML and initiated on chemotherapy. During the course of his treatment, he develops ataxia and slurred speech. Which of the following drugs could have caused this?
questions.solution:
This scenario describes a case of cerebellar toxicity and cytarabine is associated with this condition.

It is seen especially with intrathecal administration or high dose systemic use. Cerebellar toxicity manifests as ataxia and slurred speech. Cerebral toxicity (seizures, dementia, and coma) is also seen.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with deviated nasal septum is undergoing submucous resection. What is the key incision is used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Killian’s incision is used in submucosal resection. It is a slightly curvilinear incision, taken 2–3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side of the deviated nasal septum.

Option B: Shobinger incision is used in modified radical neck dissection.

Option C: Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is a septocolumellar incision taken between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella.

Option D: Weber Ferguson incision is used in maxillectomy.

Chronic HBV infection with high infectivity

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman, who cleans aquariums in a pet shop, presents with the following lesion. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fish tank granuloma or swimming pool granuloma, which is caused by Mycobacterium marinum.

M. marinum enters the body through abrasions or minor cuts on the skin, which come into contact with contaminated fresh or saltwater.

Skin lesions develop after an average incubation period of 2–3 weeks. The most common presentation is a nodule on the hand or arm that spreads in a sporotrichoid fashion, with a succession of nodules along the lymphatics, as shown below. Ulcers and abscesses may occur in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: You see the following examination being performed in the ophthal OPD. What is the instrument being used?
questions.solution:
The image shows Hertel's exophthalmometer.

Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead).

An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Luedde exophthalmometer
  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer- most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman who was brought to the ER with hemiparesis was found to have a lacunar infarction. What causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Lacunar infarcts, also called small vessel stroke, refer to infarction following atherothrombotic or lipohyalinotic occlusion of small penetrating arteries in the brain. These penetrating arteries arise from the stem of the middle cerebral artery, circle of Willis, and basilar and vertebral arteries.

The principal risk factors are hypertension and old age.

The image below shows two lacunar infarctions on a CT.

questions.text: An adolescent who is a known case of VSD is brought by his parents with complaints of breathlessness on exertion which is gradually progressive, bluish discoloration, and swelling of toes and fingers. Investigations showed features suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following is not a part of the condition?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario along with the development of pulmonary hypertension is seen in Eisenmenger’s syndrome and predominant right to left shunt (not left to right shunt) is seen here.

Gradual onset of cyanosis, dyspnoea, fatigue, and in later stages, heart failure, chest pain, headaches, syncope, and hemoptysis in a setting of congenital acyanotic heart disease, are signs and symptoms of Eisenmenger’s syndrome.

Reversal of the shunt at the level of atria/ventricles/patent ductus arteriosus due to irreversible pulmonary vascular obstructive changes is defined as Eisenmenger’s syndrome.

Features of pulmonary hypertension in Eisenmenger physiology: Right ventricular heave, narrow split S 2 with a loud pulmonic component.

Chest X-ray showing prominent pulmonary artery and right ventricle, peripheral pruning of pulmonary vessels.

ECG shows features of right ventricular hypertrophy, with spiked P waves.

Treatment: Calcium channel blockers, prostacyclin, and it's analog treprostinil and lung transplantation.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.

Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA and Western blotting is used for the detection of protein.

Northern blotting takes its name from its similarity to the first blotting technique, the Southern blot, named for biologist Edwin Southern.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with regards to a greenstick fractures?
questions.solution:
In greenstick fractures, the inner cortex (concave) bends and the outer (convex) cortex breaks. 

A greenstick fracture is a partial thickness fracture where only cortex and periosteum are interrupted on one side of the bone, while they remain uninterrupted on the other side. 

In children, the bones are more resilient and hence, greenstick fractures are more common. It is commonly seen in the shaft of forearm bones.

The given X-ray shows a greenstick fracture.

Note: In a torus fracture, compression on one side causes the other side to be buckled. Distinct fracture lines are not seen and both cortices are intact as seen below.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child diagnosed to have focal seizures was initiated on oxcarbazepine. Which of the following would be incorrect regarding the agent being used?

choices.text: Enzyme induction potency is less when compared to carbamazepine
Hyponatremia risk is less when compared to carbamazepine

questions.solution:
The risk of hyponatremia with oxcarbazepine is higher when compared to carbamazepine. 

Option A: Oxcarbazepine is a keto analog of carbamazepine. It is a prodrug. The mechanism of action of oxcarbazepine is by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels (same as carbamazepine).

Option C: Active form is metabolized by glucuronide conjugation.

Option B: Oxcarbazepine does not cause auto-induction of metabolizing enzymes. It can induce CYP enzymes but less potent when compared to carbamazepine.

questions.text: As per the WHO, which of the following is not included in the standard of living?
questions.solution:
Social security is a component of the level of living as per the United Nations and not standard of living.

According to the WHO, the standard of living includes:

  • Income and occupation
  • Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition
  • Level of provision of health, educational, and recreational services

It depends on per capita GNP.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in inducing the migration of leukocytes to sites of injury?
questions.solution:
C5a induces the migration of leukocytes to the site of injury. It functions as an endogenous chemoattractant.

Both exogenous and endogenous substances can act as chemoattractants. The most common exogenous agents include bacterial products like peptides with N-formylmethionine terminal amino acids and certain lipids. 

Endogenous chemoattractants include several chemical mediators:

  1. Cytokines - particularly those of the chemokine family (IL-8)
  2. Complement system components - particularly C5a
  3. Arachidonic acid metabolites - mainly leukotriene B4 

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding a patellar fracture?

choices.text: A cylinder cast for an undisplaced fracture of the patella is given for a period of 3 weeks
A two-part fracture of patella is treated with a cylinder cast
A skyline view of the patella may be useful in certain undisplaced patellar fractures
A bipartite patella can cause confusion in the diagnosis of a fracture patella

questions.solution:
A two-part fracture of patella is not treated with a cylinder cast which is a conservative method.

A two-part fracture of the patella is not treated conservatively because the pull of the quadriceps tendon pulls the fragments apart and does not allow the union.

A two part fracture (Displaced transverse fracture) of the patella must be reduced, and the fragments are fixed with tension band wiring using K wires and the extensor retinaculae is repaired.

An un-displaced fracture of the patella is treated with a plaster cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension. This is called as a cylinder cast and is usually left in place for a period of at least 3 weeks.

questions.text:
The investigations of a male truck driver are given below. Which of the following is he unlikely to present with?
  • VDRL - positive
  • FTA-ABs - Antibodies to T. pallidum present 
  • MRI spine - areas of focal inflammation seen in the dorsal column
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of tabes dorsalis. It presents with loss of reflexes in lower limbs, not hyperreflexia.

Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts. It is seen in tertiary syphilis. It primarily involves the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and dorsal roots.

It presents with the following clinical features:

  • Loss of reflexes in lower limbs 
  • Romberg's sign
  • Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils - accommodation reflex present, pupillary reflex absent 
  • Loss of position sense and vibration
  • Stabbing/pricking pain in the legs - this is fleeting or repetitive
  • Ataxia of the legs and gait disturbances
  • Paresthesias
  • Bladder disturbances 
  • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting - visceral crisis 

Note: Diabetic polyradiculopathy may simulate tabes.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Donated blood is screened for all of the following infections except:
questions.solution:
Donated blood is not routinely screened for kala-azar. It is screened for the following infections in the blood bank:

  • Human immunodeficiency virus
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C
  • Malaria
  • Syphilis

questions.text: A patient with impaired renal function, undergoing chemotherapy, develops methotrexate toxicity. Which of the following drugs is a methotrexate cleaving enzyme that can be used to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Glucarpidase, which is a methotrexate cleaving enzyme, can be used in this condition. Glucarpidase is an FDA approved intravenous drug for the treatment of methotrexate toxicity in the treatment of cancer patients who have impaired kidney function. 

Glucarpidase is a recombinant bacterial enzyme that breaks down methotrexate into inactive metabolites rapidly after injection. These inactive metabolites are then eliminated by the liver.

Note: Leucovorin is also a substrate of glucarpidase. Leucovorin is avoided 2 hours before and after the administration of glucarpidase to avoid its breakdown.

questions.text: Which of the following is an activator of the key enzyme required in reverse cholesterol transport?
questions.solution:
Apo A-I is the activator of Lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), the enzyme present in HDL facilitating reverse cholesterol transport.

Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) is activated by apo A-I which then converts free cholesterol(amphipathic) in HDL to cholesterol ester(hydrophobic). As a result the initial discoidal shape now becomes spherical.

This facilitates reverse cholesterol transport.

Clinical correlation: Familial LCAT deficiency will lead to failure of reverse cholesterol transport resulting in cholesterol deposition in specific peripheral tissues - the cornea, kidneys, and erythrocytes. Major complications include premature atherosclerosis, renal failure, anemia and corneal opacities. HDL cholesterol level is decreased.

questions.text: In a chancroid lesion ____

choices.text: Both ulcer and lymphadenopathy are painless
Ulcer is painful and lymphadenopathy is painless
Ulcer is painless and lymphadenopathy is painful
Both ulcer and lymphadenopathy are painful

questions.solution:
In a chancroid lesion, both ulcer and lymphadenopathy are painful.

The ulcers are multiple with purulent and haemorrhagic discharge. They have a non-indurated, erythematous base. Lymphadenopathy in the chancroid is either unilateral or bilateral.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with Gorlin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Osteoma is not a part of Gorlin syndrome.

Gorlin syndrome/basal cell naevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the PTCH gene.

Components of Gorlin syndrome include:

  • Basal cell carcinomas
  • Medulloblastoma
  • Bifid ribs
  • Odontogenic keratocysts

questions.text: Which of the following are enantiomers?
questions.solution:
D-mannose and L-mannose are enantiomers. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other.

The designation of a sugar isomer as the D- or L- form is determined by its spatial relationship to the parent compound of the carbohydrates, that is, the three-carbon sugar glyceraldehyde. The orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the penultimate carbon atom determines whether the sugar belongs to the D- or L- series. When the —OH group on the penultimate carbon atom of the sugar is on the right side, then the sugar is designated as a D- isomer. When the –OH group is on the left, it is an L-isomer.

Naturally occurring monosaccharides are D-sugars and naturally occurring amino acids are L-isomers. Racemase enzyme interconverts between D and L isomers.

Examples of enantiomers include D-glucose and L-glucose, D-fructose and L-fructose and D-mannose and L-mannose

questions.text: Thalidomide should not be used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Thalidomide use is associated with peripheral neuropathy and is usually avoided in HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy as it can worsen the condition.

It is being investigated as an orphan drug for:

  • Recurrent aphthous ulcers
  • GVHD
  • Behcet syndrome
  • primary brain malignancies
  • Kaposi's sarcoma
  • Crohn’s disease.

It is approved for use in multiple myeloma and erythema nodosum leprosum.

The given image shows characteristic molar tooth colonies of Actinomyces species.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe radicular pain of the upper extremity due to compression of the radial nerve in a space around the shoulder joint. Which of the following is false regarding this space?

choices.text: Superior border is by teres major
It contains the circumflex scapular vessels
Lateral border is by shaft of humerus
Medial border is by long head of triceps

questions.solution:
The space around the shoulder joint where the radial nerve may be compressed is the triangular interval. It contains the profunda brachii vessels.

questions.text: What is a primary transcript?

choices.text: RNA product synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction
RNA product synthesized in the 3′-5′ direction
DNA product synthesized in the 3′-5′ direction
DNA product synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction

questions.solution:
The RNA product, which is synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction, is the primary transcript. The primary transcripts are generated by RNA polymerase II.

The longest primary transcript is produced by the dystrophin gene.

questions.text: Intake of which of the following drugs can produce an acneiform eruption?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced acne (acneiform eruptions) are associated with the following:

  • Topical or systemic steroids  (most common)
  • Anabolic steroids - danazol, stanozolol
  • Anticonvulsants - carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbitone
  • Antituberculosis drugs- isoniazid, pyrazinamide

Clinically, acneiform eruptions are characteristically monomorphic.

Drugs most commonly implicated in acneiform eruptions:

  • Worldwide- steroids
  • India- isoniazid (INH)

questions.text: Pasturization is done at ______.
questions.solution:
Pasteurization of milk is done by the following methods:  

  • Holder method: Heat at 63°C for 30 minutes
  • Flash process: Heat at 72°C for 15–20 seconds

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

questions.text: All of the following are gastrointestinal manifestations seen in patients with FAP except:

choices.text: Fundal gland hyperplasia in gastric polyp

questions.solution:
Esophageal carcinoma is not associated with FAP

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is associated with gastric and duodenal polyps in approximately 50% of the affected individuals.

Most of the gastric polyps represent fundic gland hyperplasia and have limited malignant potential. Duodenal polyps are adenomatous in nature and premalignant.

Patients with FAP have an increased risk for duodenal ampullary cancer.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by___.
questions.solution:
The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by Left stellate ganglion.

Innervation of SA Node and AV Node:

The SA node develops from structures on the right side of the embryo and the AV node from structures on the left.Therefore -

ANS

SA node

AV node

Parasympathetic

Right vagus

Left vagus

Sympathetic

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to the abdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?
questions.solution:
Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child.

Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in:

  • Stable patients with no active bleeding
  • Patients younger than 55 years of age
  • Patients with grade I, II, III injuries.

Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and V splenic injury should be managed by surgery.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text: Gleason score is used in _____
questions.solution:
• Prostate cancer is graded by the Gleason system.
  • Prostate cancers exhibit heterogenicity within tissue, and so two histological areas of prostate are each scored between 1 and 5 (called as Gleason grade).
  • The current Gleason score ranges from 6-10. Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned.
  • Each group has a prognostic significance. The prognosis worsens as the score increases.
  • This appears to correlate well with the likelihood of spread and the prognosis.

questions.text: You are a resident posted in the medicine ward. A patient who has been previously diagnosed with epilepsy has an episode of seizures and becomes unconscious. You immediately call a code. The patient is unresponsive and chest rise is not appreciable but you can feel a pulse. You suspect that this is due to falling back of the tongue and decide to secure the airway using the device shown. What landmarks would you use before selecting the appropriate size?

choices.text: Incisor teeth and tragus of the ear
Corner of mouth and angle of mandible
Tip of nose and angle of mandible
Ala of nose and angle of mandible

questions.solution:
The image shows oropharyngeal airway or Guedel airway of various sizes. The landmarks used for measuring the appropriate size of this device are the corner of the mouth and the angle of the mandible or tragus.

An oropharyngeal airway is an airway adjunct which keeps the tongue from falling back onto the posterior pharynx.

It is essential to choose the correct size since inappropriately sized ones may aggravate airway obstruction. 

These airways should not be used in conscious patients as they may come into contact with the epiglottis and base of tongue. This can cause coughing, retching or laryngospasm if the pharyngeal and laryngeal reflexes are not blunted with local anaesthetic. 

Note: Nasopharyngeal airway size is chosen by measuring the distance between the tip of the nose and tragus of the ear. These airways, when well lubricated and inserted with proper technique, can be used in conscious patients to secure an airway.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the following tool:

choices.text: Malnutrition can be detected even before signs and symptoms appear
It provides an objective basis for policy making on child healthcare
It can be used to teach the importance of adequate feeding
It can be used to indicate proof of government aid

questions.solution:
The given image shows a growth chart. It is not used as proof of government aid.

The uses of growth charts are as follows:

  • Growth monitoring and diagnosis - can detect malnutrition before clinical features appear
  • Educational tool - to teach parents about the importance of adequate feeding.
  • Objective basis for planning and policy-making on child healthcares

questions.text: Sargramostim is a recombinantly engineered analogue of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Sargramostim is a recombinant human GM-CSF (Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor).

Indications for use:

  • Autologous bone marrow transplant - reduces the duration of neutropenia
  • Cancer chemotherapy - reduces the duration of neutropenia
  • Peripheral blood stem cell collection - to mobilize CD34 positive progenitor cells

It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion.

questions.text: While conducting a demographic study, you need to calculate the total dependency ratio of the study population. Which of the following will you include in the numerator while calculating this?

choices.text: Population under 10 years and above 60 years
Population under 15 years and above 60 years
Population under 10 years and above 65 years
Population under 15 years and above 65 years

questions.solution:
Population under 15 years and above 65 years are part of the numerator used to calculate the total dependency ratio. This is because this population is considered the dependant population.

The dependant population includes children below 15 years of age and adults above 65 years of age. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 - 65 years. It is also called the societal dependency ratio. It can also be divided into the young-age and old-age dependency ratios.

Note: As of mid-year 2020, the dependency ratio of India is 48.7%.

questions.text: What happens during clonal selection?

choices.text: Brothers and sisters have similar immune response
Antigens increase mitosis in specific lymphocytes
Only certain cells can produce interferon
B cell has multiple types of antigen receptors

questions.solution:
Clonal selection implies that the antigens increase mitosis in specific lymphocytes.

Clonal selection is the process by which individual T and B lymphocytes engaged by the antigen multiply selectively to create a population of antigen-reactive cells.

Clonal selection hypothesis- This hypothesis states that an antigen interacting with a receptor on a lymphocyte induces division and differentiation of that lymphocyte to form a clone of identical daughter cells. The representatives of the stimulated clone remain in the host as a source of immunological memory.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the inguinal canal?

choices.text: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and superior walls

questions.solution:
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, not in the transversus abdominis.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text:
Jeevit, a 7-year-old boy brought to you by his mother, complains of bone pain so severe that he cannot sleep. Investigations reveal:

Leukocyte count: 16,000 cells/mm3

Hemoglobin: 6 g/dl

Platelet count: 60,000 cells/mm3

Peripheral smear shows numerous immature blast cells and is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia

In this age group, which immunophenotype of ALL is most commonly encountered?
questions.solution:
B-lymphoblastic leukemia(pre-B-ALL) is the most common immunophenotype with TdT+,HLA DR+, CD10+, CD19+, CD20+, CD24+, Cy Ig + , with onset at 1-10 years of age.

The most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is B-lymphoblastic leukemia (previously termed pre-B-ALL)

Based on current WHO classification: The most common subtype of ALL is B lymphoblastic leukemia > T lymphoblastic leukemia > Mature B-cell Leukemia (Burkitt leukemia)

The production of symptoms and signs of ALL is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure. On physical examination, findings of pallor, listlessness, purpuric/petechial skin lesions, or mucous membrane hemorrhage can reflect bone marrow failure. The proliferative nature of the disease may be manifested as lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or, less often, hepatomegaly. At presentation 75% of patients have leukocyte counts of <20,000/µL; thrombocytopenia is seen in 75% of patients and hepatosplenomegaly in 30–40% of patients. Patients with joint pain may have evidence of joint swelling and effusion. Deep bone pain may be present with marrow involvement, but tenderness will not be elicited.

 

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

questions.text: A  leprosy vaccine is being introduced on a pilot basis in India. Which of the following mycobacterial species is the basis for its development?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium indicus pranii is the basis for the development of a leprosy vaccine.

The leprosy vaccine species was originally called Mycobacterium W (M.w) but was later renamed Mycobacterium indicus pranii. The vaccine is administered via intradermal route. The dose is 0.1 ml. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms.

Booster doses will be given to maintain the immunity level. These are given only in one arm.

Since its development as an anti-leprosy vaccine, Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) has been evaluated as prophylactic as well as a therapeutic vaccine against TB in animal models and clinical set-ups. Besides the presence of its unique immunogens, MIP also shares a repertoire of highly antigenic proteins of M.tb that renders it as a promising vaccine candidate.

questions.text: A woman who is on treatment for schizophrenia says that she loves her child and wants to hug him, but also thinks that he is the devil personified and wants to harm him. She is torn between the two, and can't decide what to express. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Ambivalence is the inability to decide for or against, due to the co-existence of two opposing impulses for the same thing, at the same time, in the same person.

Ambivalence is an important feature of schizophrenia. It is also seen with OCD and other borderline conditions.

Option A: Abulia is an inability to make a decision generally. Unlike ambivalence, there are no opposing impulses present.

Option C: Anhedonia is a loss of pleasure in previously pleasurable activities.

Option D: Alexithymia is an inability to recognize and describe feelings.

questions.text: For a patient with Wilson's disease, you would administer pyridoxine along with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution: Penicillamine should always be co-administered with pyridoxine (25 mg/day) as it is an antagonist to pyridoxine.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement.

Grading of ovarian cancer:

  • Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur.
  • Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. 
  • Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared to normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur. 

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: A child with cholesteatoma undergoes surgical removal via an intact canal wall procedure. Through which of the following structures is the middle ear approached?
questions.solution:
In intact canal wall surgeries, the middle ear is approached through the suprapyramidal recess.

Surgically, facial recess/posterior sinus/supra pyramidal recess is important, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall (intact canal wall technique).

Image showing the facial recess:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the Miller-Kurzrok test?

choices.text: Penetration of > 3 cm at 30 minutes is considered normal
Cervical mucus is placed alongside husband's semen on a glass slide
It is done at the time of ovulation
Jerky motility of sperm is considered normal

questions.solution:
In the Miller–Kurzrok test, sperm acquiring jerky motility after penetrating cervical mucus is considered abnormal.

The Miller-Kurzrok test is a special test done in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility. It is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction.

It is based on the basic principle that a normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms. It is done at the time of ovulation. The test consists of placing cervical mucus on a glass slide alongside the specimen of the husband's semen and studying the penetration of sperms under the microscope. The penetration of sperm > 3 cm into the mucus at 30 minutes is considered normal.

Other special tests in semen analysis include:

  • Sperm penetration test
  • Semen–cervical mucus contact test
  • Postcoital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test)

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A?
questions.solution:
Aspartate and glutamate are responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A and B of fibrinogen.

The negative charges contribute to the solubility of fibrinogen in plasma and importantly also serve to prevent aggregation by causing electrostatic repulsion between fibrinogen molecules.

questions.text: The police charged two college students with drunken driving and brought them to the hospital for confirmation of their alcohol levels. On examination, the driver did not appear drunk and denied the charges, while the other student was clearly drunk and was barely conscious. However, the blood reports came back suggesting both of them having similarly elevated levels of alcohol. Which of the following is a possible explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
The given situation can be best explained by the Mellanby effect.

The Mellanby effect is the phenomenon where an individual’s perceived level of impairment at identical blood alcohol concentration (BAC) levels is greater when the BAC is rising (while drinking) than when it is falling (after drinking).

The clip below describes the Mellanby effect seen originally in a dog experiment.

Option B: Intermediate syndrome is a delayed-onset of muscular weakness and paralysis following an episode of organophosphate (acute cholinesterase inhibitor) poisoning.

Option C: Reverse tolerance refers to the phenomenon when an individual requires a lesser dose of alcohol (drug) to obtain the same effect as before.

Option D: Grand Rapids effect or dip is a controversial effect noted in certain studies where a BAC of 0.01–0.04% slightly lowered the risk of being in a vehicle accident when compared to a BAC of 0.00%

questions.text: All are true about red muscle fibers except -
questions.solution:
The red muscle fibers are Type 1 muscle fibers with low/moderate glycolytic metabolism. Rest of the options are true regarding red muscle fibers.
