questions.text:
Which of the following features in a patient would prompt you to anticipate a difficult intubation?
  1. Mallampati class 4 airway
  2. Thyromental distance of 7.8 cm with neck extension
  3. Neck circumference of 17.5 inches
  4. Ability to extend neck at the atlantooccipital joint
  5. A history of previous difficult intubation
questions.solution:
The following are indicators of difficult intubation:

  • Mallampati class 3 and 4 airways
  • Thyromental distance <6cm with neck extension
  • Neck circumference >17 inches in men and 16 inches in women
  • An inability to extend the neck at the atlantooccipital joint
  • A history of previous difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: A woman brings her husband to the psychiatry OPD. She says he is usually shy and mature. The previous week, she saw him flirting with a girl. When confronted, he said he could not recall this at all. During the fight, he suddenly started talking in a child-like voice and began to cry. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of dissociative identity disorder. It is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

The identities or personality states are called alters, self­ states, or alter identities. Each has its own pattern of perceiving and thinking about the environment and self. It is strongly associated with severe expe­riences of early childhood trauma, usually maltreatment.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: What is the permissible dose of manmade radiation per year?
questions.solution: The permissible dose of manmade radiation is 5 rads per year.

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive man complains of fever, migraine, loss of appetite, and myalgia. On examination, splinter hemorrhages and palpable purpura are noted. On CT angiography, aneurysm and stenosis of medium-sized vessels are observed. What is the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. It is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  1. Formation of immune complexes
  2. Deposition of immune complexes
  3. Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions: 

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • SLE
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction
  • Farmer’s lung
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Type II lepra reaction
  • Henoch Schonlein purpura

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: Obturator nerve block is performed on a patient with severe chronic hip pain. Anterior division of this nerve innervates all of the following muscles except:
questions.solution:
The anterior division of the obturator nerve does not innervate the adductor magnus. It is supplied by the posterior division of the obturator nerve.

The obturator nerve arises from the anterior division of the ventral rami of L2-L4. Near the obturator foramen, it divides into anterior and posterior branches.

  • Anterior division supplies pectineus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, and gracilis
  • Posterior division supplies adductor magnus, obturator externus. It also supplies adductor brevis if the muscle is not supplied by the anterior division

The image given below shows the course of the obturator nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest tooth to erupt in a 7-month-old baby?
questions.solution:
The earliest tooth to erupt in a 7-month-old baby (primary dentition) is a mandibular central incisor.

The time of emergence of primary dentition or temporary teeth:

Tooth Emergence
Mandibular central incisor 6-8 months
Maxillary central incisor 7-9 months
Maxillary lateral incisor 7-9 months
Mandibular lateral incisor 10-12 months
First molar 12-14 months
Canine 17-18 months
Second molar 20-30 months

The deciduous teeth all emerge into the mouth by 2.5-3 years.

The time of emergence of secondary dentition or permanent teeth:

Tooth Emergence
First molar 6-7 years
Central incisors 6-8 years
Lateral incisors 7-9 years
First premolar 9-11 years
Second premolar 10-12 years
Canine 11-12 years
Second molar 12-14 years
Third molar 18-25 years

Note: 6-13 years is the age of mixed dentition. First molar emerges at 6-7 years. Second molar emerges at 12 years and third molar emerges beyond 18 years of age.

questions.text: Most radio-sensitive structure among the following is:
questions.solution:
• Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are among the most radiosensitive cells in the body.
  • Heavily irradiated bone marrow (>30 Gy) may never fully recover.

questions.text: Which of the following values indicate a normal portal venous pressure?
questions.solution:
The normal portal venous pressure is 5 to 10 mmHg. 

Normal portal blood flow is 1 to 1.5 L/minute.

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the difference between the wedge and free hepatic venous pressure, which is 1 to 5 mmHg.

HVPG interpretation:

  • Normal HVPG is between 1 and 5 mmHg.
  • Portal hypertension is present if the HVPG is ≥6 mmHg.
  • Portal hypertension typically becomes clinically significant when the HVPG is ≥10 mmHg, at which point varices may develop.
  • HVPG ≥12 mmHg, patients are at risk for variceal bleeding and the development of ascites.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolytes is measured in Gettler’s test?
questions.solution:
Gettler's test measures the chloride content of left and right side of the heart.

A difference of 25 mg% in chloride concentrations between the two sides of the heart is an indication of death due to drowning. This test was used to identify the cause of drowning. 

  • Freshwater drowning - chloride content of left heart is lower than that of the right heart
  • Saltwater drowning - chloride content of right heart is lower than that of the left heart

Gettler's claims have been refuted and the test is no longer accepted.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man is referred urgently for management of pulmonary edema. He was diagnosed with stage-5 CKD 3 weeks ago but was reluctant to start dialysis. On examination, he is confused and has a flapping tremor. Investigations are as follows. Which of his clinical features will not improve with dialysis?

Serum urea - 99 mg/dl

Serum creatinine - 5.1 mg/dl

Serum calcium - 7.1 mg/dl

Arterial blood gas - Metabolic acidosis
questions.solution:
Renal osteodystrophy does not show improvement with dialysis.

Failure of renal function leads to decreased renal vitamin D production. The resulting hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, in turn, lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism. This can be corrected only by vitamin D and calcium supplementation.

Other manifestations of renal dysfunction and uremia show improvement with regular dialysis sessions.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow and urine appears pale straw, he is otherwise well. A provisional diagnosis of breastmilk jaundice is made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Some babies need treatment with phototherapy
It is common in the second week of life

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2–4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding. 

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

"We haven't stopped breastfeeding even once for treatment of breast milk jaundice in the last 15 years!" states the AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology-2019 (2nd edition; Page no -231)

questions.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine on water is mainly due to ________
questions.solution:
The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and was started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain and dizziness. The left and right images below show her current appearance and her appearance last month, respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing skin hyperpigmentation in a patient with severe dizziness and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition. Hypocortisolism leads to hypoglycemia in these patients.

Addison’s disease is primary adrenal insufficiency characterized by the disruption of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen secretion. Primary adrenal insufficiency is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and coincident autoimmune disease occurring in these patients most frequently includes thyroid autoimmune disease, vitiligo, and premature ovarian failure.

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman goes to her family doctor as she is unable to fall asleep at night. She complains of tingling and crawling sensations over her legs at night. She also feels a strong urge to move her legs, which relieves the symptoms for a while. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Most common cause is chronic kidney disease
Most common movement disorder in pregnancy

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of restless legs syndrome (RLS) or Willis-Ekbom disease. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is not the most common cause of this condition.   

RLS is a neurological sleep disorder that can be primary or secondary. The primary form is more common. It shows autosomal dominant inheritance in most cases, but can be idiopathic. Secondary RLS is associated with the following:

  • Iron deficiency 
  • Pregnancy - most common movement disorder
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • CKD
  • Parkinson's disease
  • Multiple sclerosis

It is characterized by an uncontrollable, restless urge to move the legs. It tends to worsen during periods of inactivity and at evening or night. It is accompanied by crawling, tingling or burning sensations. These symptoms show partial or complete improvement with movement. This cycle may continue for a while and result in insomnia.

Primary RLS is managed by improving sleep hygiene and dopamine agonists (pramipexole or ropinirole) if symptoms persist. Iron supplements can also be given. In secondary RLS, the underlying cause must be treated.

questions.text: SI unit for total radiation exposure is:
questions.solution:
SI unit for total radiation exposure is Coloumb/Kg and the common unit is Roentgen.

 

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: Oxytocin is being given for augmentation of labour in a multigravida admitted to the labour room. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Receptor mediation through G-protein coupled receptors
Activation of voltage mediated Ca channel

questions.solution:
Competitive blocking of acetylcholine is not a mechanism of action of oxytocin.

Mechanism of action of oxytocin is as follows:

  • Receptor mediation through G protein-coupled receptors
  • Activation of voltage-gated Ca channel leading to calcium entry
  • Prostaglandin production by a positive feedback mechanism. This induces production of more prostaglandins and stronger contractions.

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect:
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease, i.e. true negative.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease, i.e. true positive.

False-positive are those who don't have the disease but tested positive.

False-negative are those who have the disease but tested negative.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except:
questions.solution:
Health education is an element of primary health care, not a pillar.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: Vagus nerve stimulation is used as a treatment option for _____
questions.solution:
Vagal Nerve Stimulation is used to treat patients with treatment-resistant depression.

It is the direct, intermittent electrical stimulation of the left cervical vagus nerve via an implanted pulse generator. Chronic stimulation of these nerve fibers changes activity in the brain stem nuclei which alters serotonergic activity and improves mood. 

Somatic therapies for depression:

  • Vagus nerve stimulation - left vagus nerve
  • Repeated transcranial magnetic stimulation
  • Electroconvulsive therapy
  • Phototherapy
  • Deep brain stimulation

Treatment for Depression: Cognitive behavioural therapy + Antidepressants

Patient with single depressive disorder: If response to acute phase treatment is good, the antidepressant is continued for additional 4-9 months.

Maintenance phase:

  • Given after the initial continuation phase of treatment
  • It is given for 1-3 years in patients with a history of multiple episodes, suicide attempts, and chronic episodes (> 2 years)
  • Patients with history of more than three lifetime episodes of depression should continue maintenance treatment indefinitely.

questions.text: A surgeon takes the following 2 images of a patient's arm 6 weeks apart. Which of the following mediators promote the process shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows wound healing. TGF-β (transforming growth factor-β) is responsible for wound healing.

TGF-β is produced by B and T cells and it inhibits their proliferation. It acts as a growth factor for fibroblasts and promotes wound healing. It stimulates the production of collagen, fibronectin and proteoglycans. It also promotes class switching of B cells to IgA. IL-10 is also involved in wound healing and suppression of inflammation. 

Option B: IFN-α inhibits viral replication, activates NK cells, and regulates the activity of macrophages and T cells.

Option C: TNF-α is involved in tumour cytotoxicity, phagocytic cell activation, and antiviral and antiparasitic effects. It is an acute phase protein. 

Option D: IFN-β has antiviral activity. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following is a combined immunodeficiency disorder associated with both B-cell and T-cell defects?
questions.solution:
Louis–Bar syndrome or ataxia-telangiectasia is a combined immunodeficiency disorder. 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is a syndrome complex that comprises neurologic, immunologic, endocrinologic, and cutaneous disorders. The gene involved in this condition is the mutation in the ATM gene mapped to the long arm of chromosome 11(11q22-23). The mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive. There is defective DNA repair and increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation. 

Clinical features:

  • Progressive cerebellar ataxia
  • Oculocutaneous telangiectasias 
  • Chronic sinopulmonary disease
  • High incidence of malignancy - adenocarcinomas and lymphoreticular tumors (lymphoma, leukemia, and Hodgkin's disease)
  • Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency
  • Ovarian dysgenesis and chromosomal abnormalities
  • Hypoplastic thymus
  • Ataxia and chorioathetoid movements start in infancy. 

The onset of telangiectasia is around 3 to 6 years and involves the face, conjunctiva and other parts of the body. By 12 years of age, affected children are usually confined to wheelchairs due to progressive ataxia. 

Death occurs due to sinopulmonary infection in early life or due to malignancy in the second or third decade. They lack IgA and IgE. Cell-mediated immunity is also defective. 

The image below shows ocular telangiectasia in a patient with A-T.

Other options: 

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder associated with T-cell deficiency.

Options C and D: Chediak-Higashi syndrome and tuftsin deficiency are disorders of phagocytosis.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which part of the proximal tubule is most susceptible to ischemic injury?
questions.solution:
Regions of the kidney most prone to ischemic injury are the S3 segment of the proximal tubule and the medullary thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (mTAL). These tubular areas exist physiologically in relatively lower oxygen conditions.

The S3 segment, in particular, has a much lower capability of producing energy through glycolysis under anaerobic conditions than the mTAL.

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3 days.  A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding the diagnostic methods used to detect the condition he is likely suffering from?

choices.text: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for peripheral smear examination
pLDH antigen test is specific for detection of the causative agent
Acridine orange dye is used in quantitative buffy coat method
Rapid diagnostic tests have lesser sensitivity than microscopy

questions.solution:
High-grade fever, chills and the peripheral smear showing double chromatin ring forms are suggestive of P. falciparum malaria. HRP-2 antigen detection used in rapid diagnostic tests for malaria is specific for P. falciparum. pLDH is positive for all Plasmodium spp. 

Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of antigens using immunochromatographic methods. They are less sensitive than microscopy and also cannot differentiate between species except P. falciparum. The 2 antigens detected are:

  • pLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase): Pan-malarial antigen
  • HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein 2): Specific for P.falciparum.

Parasite-F test is a rapid diagnostic test for the detection of HRP-2. The dual antigen test is a rapid diagnostic test for the detection of both pLDH and HRP-2. 

Other diagnostic methods include microscopy of peripheral blood smears, quantitative buffy coat, culture and molecular diagnosis. Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya (JSB) stain is routinely used in India to stain peripheral blood smears. In quantitative buffy coat, a small quantity of blood is centrifuged. The RBCs containing malarial parasites settle just below the buffy coat of leukocytes, on top of the normal RBCs. The tube is precoated with acridine orange dye, which induces fluorescence in the parasites (the dye stains nucleic acids which are absent in mature RBCs). The parasites appear greenish-yellow against a red background.

questions.text: Nuclei present in the floor of IV ventricle in open part of medulla are all except?
questions.solution:
The central gray matter lies beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle at this level.

Passing from medial to lateral, the following important structures:

  1. The hypoglossal nucleus
  2. The dorsal nucleus of the vagus
  3. The nucleus of the tractus solitarius
  4. The medial and inferior vestibular nuclei

The nucleus ambiguus is situated deep in the medullary reticular formation.

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for infertility. She gives a history of being employed in the printing industry. Exposure to which of the following is likely to cause this situation?
questions.solution:
A woman working in the printing industry is likely to suffer from infertility due to lead toxicity. 

More industrial workers are exposed to lead than to any other toxic metal. Occupational exposure to lead is seen in several industries including the manufacturing of storage batteries, glass, shipbuilding, printing, potteries, and rubber industries. 

The effects of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, blue-line on the gums (Burton's line), stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist & foot drop, headache, and convulsions. In young or pregnant women, prolonged lead exposure can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, and low birth weight.

The World Day for Safety and Health at Work conducted on April 28 every year promotes the prevention of occupational accidents and diseases globally.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: Which of the following is a newer biomarker to assess the prognosis in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Soluble ST-2 is a newer biomarker that can be used for determining the prognosis of patients with heart failure. Other newer biomarkers used are  galectin-3, GDF 15. 

Options B and D: Lipocalin, also known as neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL) or siderocalin, cystatin C, and IL-18 are biomarkers of acute kidney injury (AKI).

Option C: Endothelin-1 is a useful biomarker for early detection of bronchiolitis obliterans in lung transplant recipients.

questions.text:
A patient is said to have refractory ascites if the ascites does not resolve even after:
  1. Dietary sodium restriction
  2. 100mg / day spironolactone 
  3. 160mg / day furosemide
  4. 100mg / day furosemide
  5. 400mg / day spironolactone
questions.solution:
Refractory ascites is defined as the inability to mobilize ascitic fluid despite:

  • Compliance with dietary sodium restriction
  • Administration of maximum doses of diuretics -
    • 400mg of spironolactone per day and
    • 160mg of furosemide per day

questions.text: A 30-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance. It is seen in poisoning with boric acid.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a beefy red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum, is seen. The intense erythema is followed by extensive exfoliation.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with multiple tender, erythematous fluctuant skin lesions as shown in the image.  You suspect it to be a case of botryomycosis. Which of the following is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of botryomycosis is Staphylococcus aureus.

Botryomycosis is a rare chronic bacterial granulomatous disease that usually involves the skin and rarely viscera. It is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus but can also be caused by Pseudomonas, Escherichia coli, Proteus, and Streptococci. Patients present with chronic, suppurative, granulomatous skin lesions like nodules, abscesses and sinuses. 

Actinomycetoma, eumycetoma and botryomycosis are difficult to distinguish clinically but are readily distinguished with microbiologic testing or biopsy.  Granules of botryomycosis consist of loose masses of cocci. Organisms can also be seen in wound discharge or histologic specimens.

The word 'Botryo' is derived from the Greek word 'Botrys' meaning "bunch of grapes". The nomenclature is a misnomer as it is caused by bacteria and not by fungus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about immunoglobulins is false?

choices.text: IgG is used to diagnose fetal infection

questions.solution:
IgG cannot detect fetal infections because it is not produced by the fetus in significant amounts. 

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and provides natural passive immunity to the newborn.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Staphylococci except that ___.

choices.text: A majority of infections caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci are due to Staphylococcus epidermidis
Βeta-lactamase production in staphylococci is under plasmid control.
Expression of methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus increases when it is incubated at 37°C in blood agar.
Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is independent of β-lactamase production.

questions.solution:
The optimum temperature for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) expression is 30°C, whereas the optimum temperature for the growth of S. aureus is 37°C.

Other options:

Option a: More than 75% of infections caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) are due to Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Option b: Beta-lactamase production in staphylococci is plasmid mediated, whereas PBP 2A (mecA gene is chromosomal)

Option d: Resistance in MRSA is mediated by the mecA gene, which is chromosomally coded. It alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell membrane to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics. Thus, methicillin resistance in S. aureus is independent of β-lactamase production.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the bony changes in CTEV?

choices.text: Metatarsals deviate laterally at tarso-metatarsal joints

questions.solution:
• Calcaneus is in a varus position, talus is displaced medially and towards the plantar side.
  • Navicular and cuboid are also displaced medially. Then cuboid articulates with the non-articular surface of calcaneus and this is known as cuboid sign or a locked cuboid.
  • Metatarsals deviate medially and tibia shows medial torsion, rarely lateral torsion.

Note: Talocalcaneal articulation is a ball and socket joint. The anterior and middle articulation of the calcaneum forms the socket and the head of the talus forms the ball which is the dislocation in CTEV.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with recurrent UTIs, the following urographic finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous urogram shows the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole due to an obstructed (and unopacified) upper pole, referred to as the drooping lily sign, observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The duplicated collecting system is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract characterized by an incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties resulting in a variety of complete or incomplete duplications of the collecting system. It occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. As a result, the affected individual may have two collecting systems for one kidney. 

Duplex collecting systems may also be complicated by vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction or ureterocoele. When the upper pole ureter is obstructed, the lower pole collecting system appears displaced and stretched on imaging, creating the "drooping lily" sign observed in intravenous urography. 

The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage. When there are abnormalities associated with duplicating collecting systems,

  • The upper pole moiety drains inferomedially and is most commonly associated with obstruction.
  • The lower pole moiety drains superolaterally and is most commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux.

The illustration given below shows the Weigert-Meyer law.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Osteoarthritic cartilage is characterised by ________
questions.solution:
Aggrecan is decreased in the osteoarthritic cartilage.

The two major macromolecules in cartilage are

  • Type 2 collagen, which provides its tensile strength and
  • Aggrecan, a macromolecule linked with hyaluronic acid, which consists of highly negatively charged glycosaminoglycans.

IL-1 exerts effects on chondrocytes stimulating production of proteinases and suppressing cartilage synthesis and is increased in osteoarthritis.

Loss of type 2 collagen occurs.

ADAM-TS 4, and 5 which cause breakdown of cartilage matrix are increased.

questions.text: What is the effect on the cellular membrane when the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased?
questions.solution:
When the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), there is increased negativity of RMP.

RMP predominantly depends on the diffusion of K+ from inside to outside the cell. This diffusion depends on the concentration gradient with the inside of the cell having a larger concentration of K+ ions. When the extracellular concentration of K+ decreases, the concentration gradient for K+ rises. Therefore, more K+ ions diffuse out of the cell. This leaves the inside of the cell more negative relative to the extracellular space. This increases the negativity of the RMP, leaving the membrane hyperpolarised.

questions.text: What is Hardy-Weinberg law related to?
questions.solution:
The Hardy-Weinberg law is related to population genetics. Population genetics is the study of the precise genetic composition of a population and various factors determining the incidence of inherited traits in them. 

Founder effect is a violation to this law. It is due to difference in expression of the genes in founding population. This is responsible for the difference in the distribution of disease in population.

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: A pregnant woman was diagnosed with red degeneration of fibroid at 26 weeks of gestation. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.

It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

questions.text:
Which of the following Infections is / are caused by Staphylococcus aureus?
1. Erythrasma
2. Acute Paronychia
3. Chancroid
4. Bullous Impetigo
questions.solution:
Acute paronychia and bullous impetigo are caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Erythrasma is a skin disease that causes brown, scaly skin patches. It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

Paronychia is a soft tissue infection around a fingernail that begins as cellulitis but that may progress to a definite abscess. The 2 types of paronychia are as follows :

 Acute paronychia: Painful and purulent condition; most frequently caused by staphylococci

 Chronic paronychia: Usually caused by a fungal infection

Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

Bullous impetigo is a skin condition that characteristically occurs in the newborn, and is caused by a bacterial infection, most commonly by S. aureus, presenting with bullae.

 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

A. Direct infection of skin and adjacent tissues

  • Carbuncle
  • Ecthyma
  • Folliculitis
  • Furunculosis
  • Impetigo
  • Sycosis

B. Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

C. Cutaneous disease due to effect of bacterial toxin

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
  • Toxic shock syndrome
  • Staphylococcal scarlatina
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

questions.text: What is the rate-limiting step of de novo purine synthesis?

choices.text: PRPP to  Phosphoribosyl amine by PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase
PRPP to Phosphoribosyl amine by PRPP synthetase
Ribose 5-phosphate to PRPP by  PRPP synthetase
Ribose 5-phosphate to PRPP by PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase

questions.solution:
The rate-limiting step of de novo purine synthesis is the conversion of 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP) to phosphoribosylamine by PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase.

The first intermediate formed in the de novo pathway for purine biosynthesis is 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate (PRPP). The rate-limiting enzyme is PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase. This is the committed step in purine nucleotide biosynthesis.

Note: PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase is activated by PRPP and glutamine and inhibited by AMP and GMP.

Related Pearl: Enzymes of Purine Synthesis Pathway and Their Regulators

Inhibited by Amp & GMP

Activated by Glutamine

Diazanorleucine(inhibitor)

Activator pi

Inhibitors  purine ribonucleotides

Formyltransferase

Methotrexate, Anti-folate drugs

VI Synthetase

Azaserine

Adenylosuccinase ,IMP Dehydrogenase

6-mercaptopurine

IMP Dehydrogenase

mycophenolic acid

questions.text: The first layer of the sole consists of:
questions.solution:
The first layer of the sole consists of abductor hallucis.

The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers are numbered from one to four.

Muscles of the sole of the foot are:

1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digitorum brevis.

 

2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.

3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.

4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with papillary thyroid carcinoma developed a palpable lymph node in the suprasternal space of Burns. Which of the following structures is not closely related to these metastatic lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The external jugular vein is not present in the suprasternal space of Burns. It is present in the supraclavicular space, along with the supraclavicular nerve.

Contents of the suprasternal space of Burns include:

  • The jugular venous arch, formed by the anterior jugular veins
  • Sternal head of right and left sternocleidomastoid
  • Lymph nodes
  • Interclavicular ligament.

Investing layer of deep fascia encloses:

  • 2 muscles - sternocleidomastoid, trapezius
  • 2 glands - parotid and submandibular gland
  • 2 spaces - suprasternal space and supraclavicular space
  • 2 ligaments - stylomandibular and sphenomandibular ligament

The supraclavicular space includes:

  • Supraclavicular nerve
  • External jugular vein

questions.text: A patient with right flank pain and fever has renal angle tenderness on examination. Which of the following forms the boundaries of this angle?

choices.text: Lower border of 11th rib and medial border of erector spinae
Lower border of 12th rib and medial border of erector spinae
Lower border of 11th rib and lateral border of erector spinae
Lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of erector spinae

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the renal angle tenderness are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. The renal angle is formed by the lower border of the 12th rib and the lateral border of the erector spinae.

The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text: A cachexic patient with a BMI of 14 was brought to a nursing care facility. Calorie-rich food through a nasogastric tube was started. On day 3 of therapy, the patient suddenly developed a seizure. An ECG showed dysrhythmia. Which of the following findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of refeeding syndrome which results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that may occur due to rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

With refeeding, a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate stimulates insulin release, which results in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. These electrolyte disorders can result in altered myocardial function, arrhythmias, deteriorating respiratory function, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Severe hyperglycemia may result from blunted basal insulin secretion. It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter.

questions.text: As part of calculating Downe's score for a baby, you would assess all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Downe's score does not consider nasal flaring.

The severity of respiratory distress is assessed by Downe’s score and Silverman–Anderson score. Downe’s score can be applied for any gestational age. Downe’s score of >7 means impending respiratory failure. Silverman–Anderson score is more suited for preterms with hyaline membrane disease (HMD).

Downe's scoring

Score  0  1  2
Respiratory rate <60/min  60–80/min >80/min
Air entry  Normal Mild decrease Marked decrease
Cyanosis  Nil In room air On >40% O2
Grunting  None Only on auscultation Audible with naked ear
Retraction  Nil Mild Moderate

questions.text: Following a normal vaginal delivery, the placenta delivered by controlled cord traction appeared as shown below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a placenta with a small, accessory lobe. This condition is known as placenta succenturiata. 

A succenturiate placenta contains single or multiple accessory lobes. Accessory lobes are attached to the main lobe by a membrane that has a leash of blood vessels.

Option A: Bilobate placenta - it consists of two placental lobes. The cord inserts between the two lobes.

Option C: Placenta membranacea - entire surface of the fetal membranes are covered by functioning villi and the placenta develops as a thin membranous structure occupying the entire periphery of the chorion.

Option D: Placenta marginata - chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, and a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of the duct that connects the primitive gut to the ____________.
questions.solution:
The presence of meconium discharge at the umbilicus is suggestive of vitelline fistula. It occurs due to patent vitelline duct, which connects the primitive gut to the yolk sac.

The primitive gut is connected to the definitive yolk sac through a narrow stalk-like communication known as the vitellointestinal duct. It is also known as vitelline duct or yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct. 

Due to the folding of the embryo in the cephalocaudal and lateral directions, the embryo gets enclosed all around by ectoderm, except in the region through which the vitellointestinal duct passes. In this region, there is a circular aperture, which is now called the umbilical opening. The vitellointestinal duct completely obliterates by the 7th week of development.

Vitelline duct abnormalities:

  • Meckel's diverticulum: In about 2% o the individuals, a portion of the vitelline duct persists an outpouching of the ileum called, Meckel diverticulum. The diverticulum is usually asymptomatic unless it contains heterotopic pancreatic or gastric mucosa, which may lead to bleeding, ulceration, or perforation.
  • Vitelline cyst: In some individuals, both the ends of the vitelline duct transforms into fibrous cords. However, the middle portion of the duct forms a large cyst called, enterocystoma, or vitelline cyst. As the fibrous cords run across the peritoneal cavity, it may lead to intestinal obstruction, strangulation, or volvulus.

questions.text: The structure that the marked muscle in the gluteal region inserts into has ____ type of epiphysis?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and its insertion is at the greater trochanter of the femur, which is an example of traction epiphysis.

Traction epiphysis is nonarticular and does not transmit weight. They provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis. Examples of traction epiphysis include greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur. 

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with intermittent suprapubic pain, increased urinary frequency, and dysuria for 2 months. A cystoscopy revealed the presence of Hunner ulcers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hunner ulcers are chronic mucosal ulcers that are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

It is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women. It presents with intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria.

The following cystoscopic findings are seen in the bladder mucosa:

  • Fissures
  • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)

The microscopic findings include: 

  • Mucosal ulceration covered by fibrin and necrotic material
  • Increased numbers of mucosal mast cells
  • Submucosal edema

In later stages, transmural fibrosis may occur, leading to a contracted bladder. Biopsy must be done to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may clinically mimic interstitial cystitis. 

The following image shows a Hunner's ulcer in a patient with interstitial cystitis.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: Which of the following radiographs is not considered as a standard radiograph in the ATLS (advanced trauma life support) protocol?
questions.solution:
Conventional radiography is currently used in most of the institutions that have adopted the ATLS concept.

It consists of the standard three X-rays (AP chest, AP pelvis, and a lateral cervical spine) that are usually taken with portable bedside machines. The X-Ray chest and Pelvis are included in the primary survery. During Primary Survey the abdomen is evaluated with FAST, eFAST and diagnositc peritoneal lavage for detection of intraabdominal blood.

The X-Ray of spine and extremities is included in the secondary survery. Abdomen is evaluated during the secondary survey with a CT Scan along with CT head, chest and spine. These are the minimum diagnostic modalities that need to be performed on a polytrauma patient.

questions.text: While assessing the Apgar score of the newborns, you would assess and score all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Respiratory effort, not rate is a component of Apgar score.

The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 parameters explained below. It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth.

  • Color (A, appearance)
  • Heart rate (P, pulse)
  • Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace)
  • Muscle tone (A, activity)
  • Respiratory effort (R)

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: The refractive index is the maximum at the ____________.
questions.solution:
The refractive index is the maximum at the center of the lens. 

Refractive indices of the various surfaces of the eye:

Surface  Refractive Index 
Cornea 1.376
Lens- Total  1.40
Lens- Cortex (periphery) 1.386
Lens- Nucleus  1.406 (maximum)
Aqueous Humor 1.336
Vitreous Humor 1.336

The total dioptric power of the lens is about 18 D (16 to 20 D). Lens is composed of 64% water, 35% protein, and 1% lipid/carbohydrates/trace elements, and these components contribute to the refractive index of the lens.

questions.text: Which of the following is the ultimate long-term desired state towards which all the resources are directed?
questions.solution:
The goal is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed. It is long-term and not constrained by time or resources.

The plan is the blueprint for taking action in order to achieve the goal.

Option A: Target refers to the quantifiable and achievable mid-term endpoints in the plan.

Option B: Mission describes the cause of the existence of the programme.

Option D: The objectives are short-term endpoints. They are precise points in the plan. They are either achieved or unachieved.

questions.text: Which of the following indices of obesity is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres?
questions.solution:
Quetelet's index (Body Mass Index) is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density 

Related Pearl: Body mass index

questions.text: Colour doppler studies in a patient with velamentous cord insertion revealed fetal vessels which were overlying the cervical os. Which of the following is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: Bleeding is triggered by membrane rupture
Bleeding is managed by category I caesarian section

questions.solution:
The doppler findings are suggestive of vasa previa. Maternal mortality is not seen in vasa previa, but fetal mortality is seen.

Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.

Fetal mortality is high and is due to fetal exsanguination.

Investigations of vasa previa:

  • Colour flow Doppler (TVS)
  • Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells
  • Apt test (alkali denaturation test) - to detect fetal haemoglobin

Management of vasa previa:

  • No bleeding
    • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids
    • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance
    • ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section
  • Bleeding present
    • Category I emergency caesarean section is done (immediate threat to the life of mother or fetus and decision delivery interval <30 mins)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes.

Diabetic retinopathy constitutes the retinal changes seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most important factor for its development is duration of diabetes after the onset of puberty, followed by glycemic control. It is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. The presence of hypertension increases the risk of diabetic retinopathy.

First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years after diagnosis and for type 2 is done at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus is every year. Diabetes in pregnancy is followed up every 3 months.

The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.

questions.text: The factor responsible for hysteresis is _______
questions.solution:
Surfactant is the factor responsible for hysteresis.

Difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed as hysteresis.  

The alveolar environment and, specifically, the secreted factors that help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contribute to hysteresis.

Inspiration curve:

Expiration curve:

questions.text: In a plain X-ray of the abdomen, the small bowel is said to be dilated if the diameter is more than  ______.
questions.solution:
The small bowel is said to be dilated if the diameter is more than 3 cm in a plain X-ray.

The following triad of findings is specific for small bowel obstruction on plain X-ray imaging of the abdomen:

  • Dilated small bowel loops (>3 cm in diameter)
  • Air-fluid levels seen on upright films 
  • A paucity of air in the colon.

questions.text: Seligman's disease is ____.
questions.solution:
• Alpha Heavy Chain Disease (Seligman's Disease)
    • This is the most common of the heavy chain diseases.
    • It is closely related to a malignancy known as Mediterranean lymphoma, a disease that affects young persons in parts of the world where intestinal parasites are common.

questions.text: In lardaceous spleen, deposition of amyloid occurs in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Lardaceous spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in sinusoids of the red pulp.

Sago spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in splenic follicles (white pulp).

questions.text: A health committee formed under Swachh Bharat Mission is involved in constructing septic tanks in every household. Which of the following is true about a septic tank?
questions.solution:
The recommended retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours.

If the retention period is too short, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, then undue septicity results.

There are single and double-chambered septic tanks. The minimum capacity recommended for a septic tank is 500 gallons. The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

Below is an image of a double-chambered septic tank.

questions.text: The marked area given in the sleep polysomnography is of ______
questions.solution:
The marked area in the given polysomnography represents REM sleep.

The three zones in the given image represent EOG, EEG and EMG, respectively.

The following table helps identify the state of wakefulness from the graph :

    EEG EOG EMG
Active state   Fast   +   +
REM sleep  Mixed    +   -
NREM sleep   Slow   -   +

 

In the marked area,

  • EOG shows Positive activity
  • EEG shows Mixed waves
  • EMG shows Minimal activity

This is characteristic of REM sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
questions.solution:
The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma.

The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas:

  • Mitotic index - ≥10 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Tumor cell necrosis - 
    • Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas
    • Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of joint pain, fever and a rash after starting a new drug. Serology shows that he has antihistone antibodies. Which of the following drugs are unlikely to have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, joint pain and rash with positive antihistone antibodies most likely has drug induced lupus. Penicillin is not associated with causing this condition.

Drug-induced lupus is a consequence of genetic polymorphism of N-acetyl transferase 2 (NAT2) enzyme which results in slow acetylators and fast acetylators:

  • Slow acetylators of isoniazid, hydralazine, and sulphonamides can have increased toxicity that includes lupus-like syndrome
  • Fast acetylators can have decreased efficacy as a result of faster metabolism of the active drug

Antihistone antibodies are associated with drug induced lupus and can aid in confirming the diagnosis. Drugs that may result in lupus-like syndrome (The SHIP MeChaniQ has lupus-like syndrome) are:

  • Sulphonamides/ Sulfasalazine
  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Procainamide, Para-aminosalicylic acid
  • Methyldopa
  • Chlorpromazine
  • Quinidine

questions.text: In rugoscopy, patterns are obtained from
questions.solution:
Rugoscopy/palatoprint involves study of rugae in the anterior part of hard palate which are specific to an individual and permanent.

Others:

Cheiloscopy – lip prints.

Podogram – footprint.

Ear and nose prints are also used for identification of the individual.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has undergone a total thyroidectomy procedure and has been shifted to the post-op ward. 2 hours later she develops stridor and dyspnea, but her voice is normal. Which of the following vocal cord lesions is the most likely cause for her condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion.

All the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN injury.  

In bilateral abductor paralysis,

  • Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated.
  • The voice is good.
  • Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
