questions.text: Which of the following is not true about reduced(low)-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS)?

choices.text: It contains 20 mmol of potassium per litre
Citrate is provided to prevent or correct base deficit acidosis

questions.solution:
The total osmolarity of low-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is 245 mmol/L, and it is the most commonly used ORS.

  • Potassium is provided to replace the large potassium losses, thus preventing serious hypokalemia.
  • Citrate corrects base-deficit acidosis.
  • Glucose promotes the absorption of sodium and water in the small intestine.

Related Pearl: Composition of reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)

The composition of reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is as follows:

Reduced- osmolarity ORS mmol/L
Sodium  75 
Chloride 65
Glucose (anhydrous) 75
Potassium 20
Citrate 10
Total Osmolarity 245

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with an acute painful red-eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, supported with the image of the mid-dilated and vertically oval pupil is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The pupil is non-reactive to both light and accommodation.

Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow.

Angle closure can be primary, when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Classification:

Primary angle-closure suspect (PACS)
  • Gonioscopy shows posterior meshwork ITC in three or more quadrants but no peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS).
  • Intraocular pressure (IOP), optic disc, and visual field are normal.
  • No PAS are seen
  • The risk of PACG at 5 years may be around 30%.
Primary angle closure (PAC)
  • Gonioscopy shows three or more quadrants of ITC with raised IOP and/or PAS or excessive pigment smudging on the TM.
  • Normal optic disc and field.
Primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)
  • ITC in three or more quadrants, with glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
  • Optic nerve damage from an episode of severe IOP elevation, such as acute angle closure, may not appear as typical glaucomatous cupping.

Symptoms: Pain, redness, photophobia, impaired vision, watering

Signs:

  • Corneal edema- colored halos
  • Conjunctiva- congestion, chemosis
  • IOP- elevated 40–70 mm Hg
  • AC very shallow
  • Pupil- vertically oval, mid-dilated
  • Angle- completely closed, Grade 0

Treatment:

  • Immediate- Intravenous mannitol, intravenous acetazolamide followed by oral dose, topical beta-blockers, brimonidine, latanoprost
  • Definitive- Laser peripheral iridotomy, filtration surgery

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his father who observed a yellowish tinge to his skin and eyes. He gives a history of recent onset fatigue after playing football for a few minutes and cannot stay active on the playground for a long time like before. Investigations revealed isolated conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but are normal otherwise. Liver histology revealed a black pigment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of fatigue, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and black pigment on liver biopsy, termed as "black liver" is suggestive of Dubin–Johnson syndrome.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited defect in hepatocyte secretion of bilirubin glucuronide. Disease results from absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein 2, an ATP dependent canalicular transporter.

The most commonly reported symptoms are abdominal pain and fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, and slight enlargement of the liver.

Inherited conjugated hyperbilirubinemia-

Dubin–Johnson syndrome Rotor syndrome
Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein (MRP-2) Defect in anion transport
Black liver on biopsy (due to accumulation of epinephrine metabolite) Black liver is not seen
Normal levels of coproporphyrin in urine Increased levels of coproporphyrin in urine 
Gall bladder is not visualized on oral cholecystography Gall bladder is visualized on oral cholecystography

questions.text:
You administer epidural anesthesia to a patient before surgery. Which of the following methods can you use to test the adequacy of motor block in him?
  1. Electromyography
  2. Train of four ratio
  3. Modified Bromage Scale
  4. Bispectral index
  5. Spirometry
questions.solution:
Electromyography, Modified Bromage scale, and spirometry can all be used to test the adequacy of the motor block after neuraxial anesthesia.

The Modified Bromage Scale is most commonly used, but the disadvantage is that this represents only lumbosacral motor fibers.

Modified Bromage scale

0: No motor block

1: Inability to raise extended leg; Able to move knees and feet

2: Inability to raise extended leg and move knee; Able to move feet

3: Complete block of motor limb

Electromyography and pulmonary function tests (spirometry) have been used to measure abdominal and thoracic motor function, but these are neither practical nor specific.

Train of four ratio and bispectral index are used in monitoring a patient under general anesthesia.

questions.text: A DMSA scan can be performed in all of the following cases except:

choices.text: To look for renal scarring in a child with vesicoureteric reflux
To evaluate a patient with a duplex renal collecting system
To assess renal perfusion in a man with renal artery stenosis
To confirm the presence of an ectopic kidney in a patient

questions.solution:
Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan cannot be used to measure renal plasma flow as it can be only seen on dynamic scans. 

The Tc-99m DMSA scan is used for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules with longer retention than other agents. It allows better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans. It is used for the following:

  • Evaluation of renal structure and morphology
  • Detection of scarring and pyelonephritis
  • Evaluation of renal anatomical abnormalities

Note: Captopril DTPA is used for screening in patients with renovascular hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following do not synthesise relaxin during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Relaxin is not synthesised by the fetal adrenal gland in a pregnant woman. It is synthesised by corpus luteum, decidua and placenta. 

Relaxin is a placental protein hormone. Plasma levels peak between 8 and 12 weeks of gestation and decline thereafter to lower levels that persist until term.

Functions of relaxin are:

  • Relaxation of myometrium and quiescence of early pregnancy
  • Enhancement of the glomerular filtration rate
  • Endometrial vascular remodelling by inducing secretion of VEGF

questions.text: A patient presents with blurring of vision and a painless swelling over his left elbow which has gradually been increasing in size over the past 1 year. On examination, he is noted to have patchy depigmentation on his legs. Which of the following vectors transmits the disease he's suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. It is transmitted by blackfly.

The usual presentation of onchocerciasis is the formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients also present with patchy depigmentation on the legs called leopard skin.

The presence of microfilaria in the eye causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which can lead to blindness.

Blackfly is also called Simulium. It has a flight range of almost 100 miles, making control of adult flies difficult. Abate is widely used as a larvicidal insecticide. The image given below shows a blackfly.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy developed psoriatic lesions as seen in the image below following a bout of beta-hemolytic streptococcal tonsillitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic lesions as seen in the image following a bout of beta-hemolytic streptococcal tonsillitis in a child are suggestive of guttate psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. Guttate psoriasis is a type of psoriasis occurring as a sudden onset shower of small lesions seen diffusely over the body, more on the trunk and proximal limbs. It is more common in children and young adults, following infection with group A streptococcus, and is often the first presentation of psoriasis. It can also occur as a flare-up in adults with plaque psoriasis that began in childhood. Lesions usually resolve over about 3 months. Some patients with acute guttate psoriasis might develop plaque psoriasis in the future.

Treatment:

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials - Recurrent episodes may be related to the pharyngeal carriage of the responsible streptococcus by the patient or close contact. A course of semisynthetic penicillin with rifampin may be required to clear chronic streptococcal carriage.
  • Phototherapy - Broad-band ultraviolet B (UVB)- Response is better with broadband UVB over narrow-band UVB. 

Other options:

Option A: Inverse psoriasis or flexural psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis refers to psoriasis of the flexural areas such as the inguinal creases, axillae, inframammary, and other body folds. Unlike characteristic lesions of psoriasis, these plaques are thin, with minimal or no scaling. The surface is glazed with fissuring.

Option B: Pustular psoriasis is the appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions which may be generalized or localized. 

Option D: Plaque psoriasis or discoid psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis. It presents with pruritis and a papulosquamous rash. Lesions can be described as red, scaly, and a well-defined demarcation from the normal skin. The scales often appear white and silvery. The lesions may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They are seen in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: What is Sullivan's index?

choices.text: Years of life lost due to premature death

questions.solution:
Sullivan's index measures life expectancy free from disability. Sullivan's index = Life expectancy - Years of disability

It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current pattern of mortality and disability continues to apply.

It is also called disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) and active life expectancy. It doesn’t take into account premature death.

questions.text: Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of chloramphenicol, especially in premature infants.

It develops due to the developmental deficiency of the enzyme glucoronyl transferase. This enzyme metabolizes chloramphenicol in neonates. Its deficiency leads to an inability to excrete unconjugated drugs adequately through renal excretion.

The initial symptoms are: 

  • Vomiting
  • Refusal to suck
  • Irregularly rapid respiration
  • Periods of cyanosis.

After 1-2 days:

  • Flaccid baby
  • Hypothermia
  • Ashen-gray color skin discoloration

If there is a recovery, usually there are no sequelae.

questions.text: A 26-year-old Chinese translator presents with fever, jaundice and splenomegaly. His Hb is 6 g% and peripheral smear with brilliant cresyl blue is given below. Which of the following globin chains would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheral smear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of α thalassemia where the HbH is composed of tetramers of β chains (β4).

Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is more common in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acute episodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs.

The decreased α chain production leads to a relative excess of β chains. This leads to the formation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidation which causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increased sequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

questions.text: The amount of folic acid given in prophylactic therapy for Iron deficiency anaemia according to MoHFW _________
questions.solution:
500 μg daily of folic acid is given as prophylactic therapy along with 60 mg of elemental iron for a minimum of 180 days for Iron deficiency anaemia according to Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoFHW).

 

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text:
A second autopsy is performed in which of the following scenarios?
  1. The relatives are not satisfied with the first autopsy report
  2. The first autopsy was not performed in the light of the circumstances which are now available
  3. The investigating authority demands a second autopsy
  4. The first autopsy was done in the absence of the investigating officer
  5. The first autopsy was done in the absence of relatives
questions.solution:
A second autopsy may be performed when relatives are not satisfied, new circumstances emerge, or investigating officer demands it.

After an autopsy, when a repeat medicolegal postmortem is performed with the authorization by law it is called a second autopsy.

The magistrate/commissioner of the police vested with such power, orders the second autopsy.

A second autopsy may be performed in the following cases:

  • The relatives of the deceased are not satisfied with the first autopsy report and they have pointed out certain lapses in the first autopsy.
  • The first autopsy was not performed in the light of the circumstances which are now available.
  • The investigating authority demands a second autopsy for setting the investigation on the right track.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the type of cartilage shown in the histological image below?

choices.text: It is present in epiphyseal plate

questions.solution:
The above image shows a section of fibrocartilage stained with trichrome stain. Fibrocartilage is not covered by perichondrium.

The fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendon and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of thick collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles.

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by:

  • Presence of chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing abundant collagen fibres

Options A & D: Both the epiphyseal plate and bronchi have the hyaline type of cartilage.

Note: The colour of cartilage should not be considered while deciding its type, as it largely depends on the type of stain used. Instead, the structure or organisation of the cartilage tissue should be considered.

questions.text: The best marker for electroconvulsive therapy is:
questions.solution:
According to the latest research, ECT increases the levels of Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor and this mediates the reponse to ECT in drug resistant depressed patients.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: You received a stool sample of a patient suspected to have dysentery in the microbiology lab.  On microscopy, you observe the structures shown in the image. What other findings you will expect to see in this stool sample?

choices.text: RBCs as discrete or in rouleaux

questions.solution:
The given image is showing erythrophagocytosis (trophozoite with ingested RBCs) and this in the stool sample of a patient with features of dysentery is indicative of amoebic dysentery. The other stool microscopic finding seen in amoebic dysentery is Charcot-Leyden crystals.

The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the only characteristic that can be used to morphologically differentiate E. histolytica from the nonpathogenic entamoeba.

Amoebic dysentery: Clinically, it has an insidious onset with localized abdominal tenderness. Tenesmus, toxicity, and fever are absent. Under microscopy, RBCs are clumped, yellowish-brown in color. Charcot-Leyden crystals and eosinophils are present.

Charcot-Leyden crystals are diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile structures that may be seen in stool specimens under microscopy and represent breakdown products of eosinophils.

The below image shows Charcot-Leyden crystals:

questions.text: What is the most common type of choledochal cyst?
questions.solution:
Type I is the most common type of choledochal cyst (75%).

Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra- and/or extra-hepatic biliary system. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: What is the most common site for a thyroglossal cyst?

choices.text: At the level of the hyoid

questions.solution:
The most common site for thyroglossal cyst is infrahyoid region.

It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct:

  • Infrahyoid (most common site)
  • Region of thyroid cartilage
  • Suprahyoid
  • Floor of mouth
  • Beneath foramen caecum

 

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. Normally, the thyroglossal duct regresses once the thyroid gland has completely descended. If it fails to regress, a thyroglossal duct cyst is formed.

It can be differentiated from other midline neck swellings by the following features: 

  • Can be moved sideways but not vertically
  • Moves with both deglutition and tongue protrusion

Surgical management of a thyroglossal cyst is via Sistrunk procedure.

Note: Presence of thyroid in the midline posterior 1/3rd of tongue is called lingual thyroid. It is due to failure of descent of the thyroglossal duct during development.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady with papillary thyroid cancer is being treated with radioactive iodine 131. What is the half-life of this isotope?
questions.solution:
The half-life of radioactive I 131 is 8 days

I131 emits both beta and gamma rays. It is used both for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes for thyroid disorders. 

I127 is the stable isotope of iodine. 

I123 is the radioactive isotope of iodine that emits only gamma rays. The action is short-lived with a half-life of around 13 hours. It is indicated for diagnostic indications only. 

Related Pearl: Half life of radio isotopes

questions.text: A nurse in the nephrology ward is managing the drug inventory for patients with severe renal failure. Which of the following beta-blockers is least likely to be present in the drug charts?
questions.solution:
Sotalol is least likely to be present in the treatment charts as it is contraindicated in severe renal failure. It has low lipid solubility and is excreted primarily unchanged in the urine.

Carvedilol, metoprolol and labetalol are metabolised by the liver and can be used in renal failure.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with a well-demarcated, coin-shaped erythematous plaque on his left shin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of nummular dermatitis or nummular eczema.

The diagnostic lesion of nummular dermatitis is a well-demarcated coin-shaped erythematous plaque with vesicles surrounding it. Later central clearing (resolution) and peripheral extension lead to annular or ring-shaped lesions. Initially, it is red and pruritic but later, it becomes more scaly and less exudative. 

Common locations involved are: 

  • Trunk
  • Extensor surfaces of extremities: 
    • Men - Pretibial areas
    • Women - Dorsal aspects of hand

The image below shows nummular dermatitis. Note the typical shape and demarcation of the lesion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with generalized weakness and lightheadedness for 2 weeks. Blood investigations were notable for decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH. Her peripheral smear showed RBC fragments. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fatigue and decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. It is associated with a deficiency of vitamin E.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia.

Note: Vitamin K deficiency does not cause hemolysis. It causes manifestations of impaired coagulation, such as easy bruisability, mucosal bleeding, etc. However, vitamin K toxicity can cause hemolysis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is the presence of gallstones (50-70%). The second most common cause is alcohol abuse (25%).

Causes of acute pancreatitis: (Mnemonic: I GET SMASHED)

  • I – Idiopathic
  • G – Gallstones
  • E – Ethanol
  • T – Trauma
  • S – Steroids
  • M – Mumps, malignancy (pancreatic cancer)
  • A – Autoimmune
  • S – Scorpion sting
  • H – Hypercalcemia, hypertriglyceridemia (Usually more than 1000 mg/dL)
  • E – Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • D – Drugs

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dendritic ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus. Corneal guttata are not seen in HSV infection. They are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. It is a feature of corneal dystrophies.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with Guillian-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Bladder dysfunction is not usually severe and does not appear early in the course of Guillain-Barre Syndrome(GBS). If bladder dysfunction is a prominent feature and comes early in the course, diagnostic possibilities other than GBS should be considered.

GBS is an acute demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. It is an autoimmune disorder triggered by infections like:

  • Campylobacter jejuni 
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Epstein Barr virus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Varicella zoster virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza

It manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis, with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is ascending paralysis. Proximal and distal muscles are equally involved. The lower cranial nerves are frequently affected, causing bulbar weakness.

questions.text: All the following muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes except ______.
questions.solution:
All the muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes except palatoglossus. It is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch.

Hence all the muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except the palatoglossus muscle which is supplied by the pharyngeal plexus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female was worried about the shape of her nose. She feels it is not symmetrical and looks ugly. She often compares her nose with that of others to look for the flaw. She also checks her nose often in the mirror. Due to this, she sometimes avoids social gatherings. Which of the following best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
The given history suggests the presence of body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) in the patient.

BDD is characterized by persistent preoccupations about one or more perceived defects or flaws in one’s appearance, but the defects or flaws are negligible or not even observable to others. In response to their appearance concerns, individuals with BDD demonstrate a range of mental acts:

  • Comparing themselves with others
  • Checking in the mirror
  • Camouflaging their perceived flaws
  • Avoidance- from minor social avoidance to being housebound.

The specific focus of BDD on appearance serves to differentiate it from other conditions characterized by repetitive behaviours.

Note: Olfactory reference syndrome is characterized by repetitive concerns about having a foul odour. This leads to a range of repetitive behaviours such as washing or changing one’s clothes.

questions.text: You are asked to conduct an autopsy of a person who was found dead at his home. You notice the given findings on the body. Which test can be used to differentiate this from antemortem bruising?
questions.solution:
The given image shows postmortem hypostasis. The classic test used to differentiate a bruise from hypostasis is the incision test. 

The suspected area is incised to see if the underlying blood is intravascular (hypostasis) or infiltrating the tissues outside the vessels (contusion).

Option A: Gettler's chloride test is used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. It is not widely used now. 

Option C: In the precipitin test, a specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid, blood, or saliva. A positive test will confirm human origin.

Option D: Breslau's second life test is done to determine whether a child was born alive or not.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man on antidepressant therapy with TCAs for the past five years is being switched to SSRIs. Which of the following would not be an advantage of this change?
questions.solution:
SSRIs have a higher incidence of sexual dysfunction when compared to TCAs. 

SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can result in loss of libido, delayed ejaculation, and interference with orgasm.

Option A: The potential of SSRIs to lower the seizure threshold is less than that of TCAs.

Options B and D: SSRIs have a selective action on serotonin reuptake with no effect on cholinergic or histaminergic receptors.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of multiple episodes of passing blood in the urine. Which of the following condition is not associated with this symptom?
questions.solution:
Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) presents with acute-onset microscopic hematuria not recurrent gross hematuria.

Causes of recurrent gross hematuria:

  • Alport’s syndrome: hereditary nephritis
  • Thin glomerular basement membrane disease
  • IgA nephropathy: Berger’s disease 
  • Idiopathic hypercalciuria/hyperuricosuria
  • Sickle cell nephropathy (papillary necrosis)

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanisms employed by HIV to evade neutralizing process?

choices.text: Hypervariability in the sequence of the envelope

questions.solution:
HIV employs at least three mechanisms to evade neutralizing responses:

  • Hypervariability in the primary sequence of the envelope
  • Extensive glycosylation of the envelope
  • Conformational masking of neutralizing epitopes

The principal targets of neutralizing antibodies against HIV are the envelope proteins gp120 and gp41.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child has a history of fever and the rash, as shown in the image, since 2 days. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 most classically causes erythema infectiosum (also called fifth disease), a mild febrile illness with rash.

Clinical features include prodromal symptoms, such as fever, coryza, headache, nausea, and diarrhea. These constitutional symptoms coincide with the onset of viremia.

Two to five days later, the classic erythematous malar rash appears with relative circumoral pallor (the so-called slapped cheek rash). This facial rash is often followed several days later by a reticulated or lacelike rash on the trunk and extremities.

It is also referred to as "fifth disease" because it was fifth in a list of historical classifications of common skin rash illnesses in children.

Parvovirus can cause transient aplastic anemia in individuals with hematologic abnormalities. 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)?

choices.text: Vague abdominal discomfort is a part of the diagnostic criteria
Diagnostic criteria should be fulfilled for at least 3 months to make the diagnosis
Painless diarrhea or constipation is not a part of the diagnostic criteria
Symptoms must be present at least once a week

questions.solution:
Vague abdominal discomfort is not a part of the diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Rome IV criteria have replaced abdominal discomfort with abdominal pain, and pain is now a prerequisite clinical feature of IBS. 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation, or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhea or constipation does not fulfill the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhea-predominant IBS. The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil has been shown to be effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is not derived from the paramesonephric duct. It is a remnant of the mesonephric/ Wolffian duct.

questions.text: “The dream is the (disguised) fulfillment of a (suppressed, repressed) wish.”- Sigmund Freud. Which of the following mechanisms is not included in the 'Interpretations of dreams' written by Sigmund Freud?
questions.solution:
Repression is not the mechanism through which dreams manifest. It is the barrier due to which the thoughts and events stored in our unconscious mind do not come out to our conscious mind and awareness.

According to the 'Interpretation of dreams' written by Sigmund Freud, dreams represent unconscious wishes or thoughts which are not accepted by the conscious mind. They manifest through the following mechanisms:

Symbolism: Representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected. 

Displacement: Transfer of mental energy from one object to a substitute or symbolic representation of the object. 

Condensation: Mechanism by which multiple unconscious wishes combine into a single image or when one unconscious wish gets distributed into multiple images. 

Projection: Attributing one’s own unacknowledged feelings to others. 

Secondary elaboration: Process by which the ego organizes illogical, bizarre and absurd images into a more coherent form in dreams.

questions.text: A patient with anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint is found to have compression of the axillary artery. However, the blood supply of the arm seems to be non-compromised. Anastomoses between which of the following vessels maintain this circulation?

choices.text: 3rd part of subclavian and 3rd part of axillary artery
1st part of subclavian and 1st part of axillary artery
3rd part of subclavian and 1st part of axillary artery
1st part of subclavian and 3rd part of axillary artery

questions.solution:
Anastomosis around the scapula maintains circulation to the upper limb if the blood supply is interrupted (fractures or dislocation of the shoulder joint). Anastomosis occurs between the 1st part of the subclavian artery and the 3rd part of the axillary artery. These arteries also anastomose with intercostal arteries.

The axial artery of the upper limb is the subclavian artery.

Anastomosis around the scapula:

Deep branch of transverse cervical artery   Thyrocervical trunk
Circumflex scapular artery Subscapular artery
Inferior angle of scapula Deep branch of transverse cervical artery Thyrocervical trunk
Subscapular artery 3rd part axillary artery
Acromion process Thoraco-acromial artery (Acromial branch) 2nd part axillary artery
Suprascapular artery (Acromial branch) Thyrocervical trunk
Posterior circumflex humeral artery (Acromial branch) 3rd part axillary artery

questions.text: When performing the test on a patient as shown in the image, you noticed that there was tenderness and resistance on flexion. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
The given findings can be seen in a patient with DVT and this is known as Homan’s sign i.e. calf tenderness and resistance on forced ankle dorsiflexion.

Moses Sign - calf tenderness on squeezing the calf from sides.

Lowenberg’s sign- pain when blood pressure cuff placed on the calf is inflated to 80 mm of Hg

questions.text: Which of the following findings will you not expect to see in a patient with SIADH?

choices.text: Normal serum urea and creatinine levels

questions.solution:
SIADH does not cause hypernatremia. SIADH is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. 

The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water in the body. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt in the urine, leading to urine sodium level of > 20 mEq/L in these patients. Thus, the level of water reaches a steady state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur, giving rise to hyponatremia.

SIADH is characterized by low levels of uric acid, normal blood pressure, and normal urea and creatinine levels.

SIADH is diagnosed based on the following criteria (Bartter-Schwartz criteria):

1. Reduced serum osmolality
2. Urine osmolality > Serum osmolality
3. Clinical euvolemia
4. Increased levels of urinary sodium
5. Absence of other causes of hyponatremia like pituitary, renal, adrenal, thyroid or liver diseases.

questions.text: What is the summating potential: action potential ratio seen in Ménière’s disease on electrocochleography?
questions.solution:
Summating potential: action potential ratio (SP: AP) >0.4 or 0.5 are consistent with a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. 

Normally, the ratio of SP to AP is 0.3 (suggestive of normal cochlear function).

questions.text: In a woman receiving artificial reproductive therapy, the inner cell mass divides on the 7th day. Which of the following complications is not seen in the resulting multifetal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The division of the inner cell mass on the 7th day will result in monochorionic diamniotic type of twin pregnancy. Cord entanglement is seen in monoamniotic twins and not in diamniotic twins.

The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below.

Monozygotic types Time of zygote division
Dichorionic diamniotic <72 hours
Monochorionic diamniotic (more common) 4-8 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic  8-12 days
Conjoined twins >12 days

Complications in monochorionic diamniotic twins occur due to placental vascular anastomoses. They include:

  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) or acardiac twin
  • Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS)

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high fetal death rate. This is due to the following complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient requires percutaneous coronary intervention. He was given an IV infusion of a reversible ADP receptor inhibitor. Which of the following drugs was used?
questions.solution:
Cangrelor is a parenteral, reversible ADP receptor (P2Y12 receptor) inhibitor, administered intravenously.

Abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban are parenteral agents too but, they are GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar

questions.text:
Which of the following nucleotide triphosphate targets ATCase for feedback regulation?

(ATCase - aspartate transcarbamoylase)
questions.solution:
Both cytidine triphosphate and adenosine triphosphate target aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) for feedback regulation.

ATCase, the catalyst for the first reaction unique to pyrimidine biosynthesis, is a target of feedback regulation by two nucleotide triphosphates: cytidine triphosphate (CTP) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP). CTP is an end product of the pyrimidine biosynthetic pathway. It inhibits ATCase, whereas the purine nucleotide ATP activates it.

High levels of ATP can overcome the inhibition by CTP, enabling synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides to proceed even when purine nucleotide (CTP) levels are elevated.

questions.text: All are true about T-cell receptors (TCR) except that ______.

choices.text: In 95% of T cells, the TCR consists of  α and  β polypeptide chains.
γδ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules.
Each TCR is non-covalently linked to six polypeptide chains, which form the CD3 complex.
The linked CD3 complex and ζ chains initiate activating signals.

questions.solution:
γδ TCR recognize different type of antigens without the requirement of MHC, whereas the αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. 

Each T cell recognizes a specific bound antigen by means of an antigen-specific T-cell receptor (TCR). 

There are two types of T cell receptors:

  • αβ TCR (95%) recognizes peptide antigens that are presented by MHC molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells.
  • γδ TCR(5%) recognizes peptides, lipids, and small molecules, without a requirement for display by MHC proteins. They have particular localization patterns in the mucosal tissues, which protect against microbes that try to enter through epithelia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the lower leg as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.

Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation.

Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

questions.text: What is the most common presenting symptom of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.

Genital tuberculosis mostly presents in young women in the reproductive age group. It can present as:

  • Infertility is the only complaint in 35-60 % of cases. Of these, 75% of women present with primary infertility.
  • Menstrual abnormalities are seen in 10-40% of cases.
  • Asymptomatic in 10% of cases.
  • Other symptoms like fever and malaise can be seen.

The treatment of infertility in women with genital TB depends on the condition of the endometrium. If the endometrium is receptive and the uterus is normal, then assisted reproductive techniques such as in-vitro fertilisation can be tried. If the endometrium is unfavourable then surrogacy may be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a H2 receptor blocker?
questions.solution:
Moxonidine is an imidazoline receptor agonist used in the treatment of hypertension.

H2 blockers:

  • Cimetidine
  • Ranitidine
  • Famotidine
  • Nizatidine
  • Roxatidine

questions.text: A 3-day-old child developed lethargy, poor feeding, and hypotonia. An inborn error of metabolism (IEM) panel was sent. Reports reveal hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia, and homocitrullinuria. What is the most likely defect?
questions.solution:
This child with lethargy, poor feeding, and labs showing hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia, and homocitrullinuria most likely has hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia and homocitrullinuria syndrome (HHH syndrome). This condition is due to an ornithine transporter defect.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A man, presented with multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting containing undigested food particles within one-hour post meals. On physical examination, he was found to be anemic and cachexic. CECT abdomen revealed diffuse infiltration of a neoplastic growth into the stomach wall. What Bormann’s classification does this tumor belong to?
questions.solution:
The history and investigation findings are suggestive of gastric outlet obstruction caused by a diffusely infiltrating type of gastric carcinoma. This is commonly known as linitis plastica and it is classified as type IV in Bormann’s classification system. 

Related Pearl: Borrmann’s classification of stomach cancer

questions.text: Which cells in the bone marrow are referred to as nurse cells?
questions.solution: Nurse cells are specialized macrophages in the bone marrow that assist in the development of red blood cells (RBCs).

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a dilatation and curettage procedure comes to the clinic 6 months later for a follow-up visit. She informs you that since the procedure, she has had scanty blood loss during menses which only lasts for 1-2 days. What is this pattern of bleeding called?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the pattern of bleeding is called hypomenorrhea. Hypomenorrhea along with a prior history of dilatation and curettage are suggestive of partial Asherman's syndrome.

Hypomenorrhoea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding. It can be seen in:

  • Partial Asherman's syndrome - uterine synechiae, causing scarring
  • Oral contraceptive use 
  • Perimenopausal age group

questions.text: The parasitic  mitochondrial toxicity action of atovaquone is increased by ___________.
questions.solution:
Synergy between proguanil and atovaquone results from the ability of the nonmetabolised proguanil to enhance the mitochondrial toxicity of atovaquone. 

Proguanil is oxidised to two major metabolites, active cycloguanil that inhibits the bifunctional dihydrofolate-thymidylate synthestase and the inactive 4-chlorophenyl biguanide. 

Both cycloguanil and 4-chlorophenyl biguanide are not responsible for synergistic action of proguanil with atovaquone.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs due to a defect in δ granules of the platelets?
questions.solution:
Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome occurs due to a defect in platelet δ granules.

Platelet granules disorders include: 

  • Gray platelet syndrome - involves α granules and characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets that appear pale on the peripheral smear (due to deficiency of the α granules)
  • Quebec platelet syndrome - defect in α granules 
  • Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome - defect in δ granules and characterized by hypopigmentation and bleeding manifestation
  • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome - mutations in the WASp gene expressed in the X chromosome and characterized by microthrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest diameter of the fetal head?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the bitemporal diameter is the smallest. It is the distance between the anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture and usually measures 8 cm. This is the smallest engaging diameter.

Option A: The biparietal diameter is a transverse diameter between two parietal eminences, measuring 9.5cm.

Option B: The suboccipitofrontal diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 10 cm. 

Option C: The suboccipitobregmatic diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 9.5 cm. 

Note: The bimastoid diameter is a transverse diameter. It is the smallest diameter in the fetal skull at about 7.5 cm. However it is not clinically relevant as it does not engage.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the finding given in the CT abdomen?
questions.solution:
The given CT abdomen depicts a swirling appearance of the mesentery and superior mesenteric vein around the superior mesenteric artery known as the whirlpool sign or whirl sign, seen in patients with midgut volvulus.

The whirlpool sign is seen when a structure twists upon itself. It is most commonly described in the abdomen where the bowel rotates around its mesentery, with mesenteric vessels creating the whirls. Whirlpool sign is seen in several settings, which include malrotation complicated by midgut volvulus, caecal volvulus, sigmoid volvulus, and closed-loop bowel obstruction. It can also be seen in ovarian torsion.

The marked CECT image below shows the whirlpool sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text:
Which among the following are contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix?
  1. Pelvic inflammatory disease
  2. Vaginal stenosis
  3. Post-menopausal status
  4. Adenocarcinoma
  5. Associated prolapse
questions.solution:
Post-menopausal status is not a contraindication for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix.

Contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix include:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Young patient (to preserve ovarian function)
  • Associated myoma, prolapse, ovarian tumor, genital fistula
  • Vaginal stenosis
  • Adenocarcinoma or adenosquamous carcinoma – surgery preferred.

questions.text: Receptors on cell membrane that activate ion channel after binding with agonists are_____
questions.solution:
Nicotinic cholinergic receptors activate an ion channel after binding with its agonist. These receptors are called ligand-gated channels or ionotropic receptors.

Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and function. They are:

  • Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in ionic conductance.
    • Important for fast synaptic transmission.
    • Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype).
  • G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated channels on neuronal membranes.
    • Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 5HT3) and opioid receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors is not caused by microbes?
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma carcinoma of the lung is not associated with microbial etiopathogenesis. It is associated with smoking and genetic predispositions.

questions.text: Which of the following image shows the Duncan method?
questions.solution:
Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. 
 

Comparison between two types of placental separation methods:

Schultze method Duncan method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour. 

One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwards and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated.

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal autonomic cephalgia except:

choices.text: Cluster headache is more common in males
SUNCT has highest attack frequency rate
Cutaneous trigger is seen in cluster headache

  • Indomethacin is effective in paroxysmal hemicrania,hemicrania continuum, and primary sexual/ exercise headache
  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of cytochrome oxidase?
questions.solution:
Cu2+ is a component of cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome C oxidase is complex IV of the ETC.

Components include two heme groups a and a3, and copper (Cu). It is an irreversible complex.

It receives electrons from complex III (Q-cytochrome C oxidoreductase). Components are Cyt b, Cyt c1. 

The final electron acceptor from complex IV is oxygen and it is reduced to water.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man is rushed to the ED with severe chest pain and is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. Which of the following can be used to assess the area of infarction in this patient?

ED- Emergency department
questions.solution: Technetium 99m pyrophosphate is used in hot spot imaging in acute myocardial infarction. It accumulates in the damaged myocardium and the area of infarct appears as a hot spot.

questions.text: What are rotationally unstable, but vertically stable pelvic ring fractures classified as?
questions.solution:
Rotationally unstable, but vertically stable pelvic ring fractures are classified as Tile type B. 

Two classification systems are used in the evaluation of pelvic ring fractures:

1. The Tile classification provides an assessment of the stability of the pelvis. It helps the surgeon predict the need for surgery. Pelvic ring fractures are classified into 3 types: 

Tile classification Stability Management
Type A Rotationally and vertically stable Conservative
Type B Rotationally unstable and vertically stable External fixation is used for definitive management. Anterior fixation is additionally done if pubic bones have separated by more than 2.5 cm.
Type C Rotationally and vertically unstable  Posterior fixation is done for vertical stability along with external fixation.

2. The Young and Burgess classification is based on the mechanism of injury. It helps the surgeon predict the severity of the injury, blood loss, and deformity or displacement. 

Note: Neer classification is used for proximal humerus fractures.

questions.text: During a post-mortem examination, the forensic expert reports a peculiar chocolate-colored discoloration of the body. It did not blanch on pressure. Which of the following statements is false regarding this scenario?

choices.text: The discolouration is due to formation of methemoglobin
This condition is associated with poisoning by nitrates
The discolouration is likely to disappear in 24-48 hours after death
The victim could have been saved by the timely use of methylene blue

questions.solution:
The chocolate-brown discoloration which does not blanch on pressure is suggestive of postmortem hypostasis/ lividity. It usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. 

Chocolate-coloured post-mortem lividity is associated with nitrates, nitrites, aniline, bromates, chlorates. It is due to the formation of methemoglobin.

Toxicity from nitrates can be treated with methylene blue to reverse the formation of methemoglobin.

Related Pearl: Post-mortem Staining in Poisonings

Poisoning Color of lividity
Carbon monoxide Cherry red
Cyanide Brick red or Dark pink
Phosphorous, acute copper poisoning Dark brown
Opium Black
Hydrogen sulphide Blue-green
Nitrate, nitrite, aniline, potassium chlorate Red-brown or chocolate brown
Potassium cyanide Deep blue
Clostridium perfringens infection Bronze
Hypothermia Bright pink

questions.text: The transient receptor potential (TRP) channel that is most active at normal skin temperature is _______.
questions.solution: At normal skin temperatures, TRPV3 is the most active receptor.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant who was started on a high-protein diet after weaning from breastfeeding developed severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and an unusual swimming pool odor. A history of similar illness was noticed in his siblings and his father. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the characteristic swimming pool odor describe Hawkinsinuria.

Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD.

In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal. Affected individuals excrete hawkinsin (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid), and its metabolites.

Treatment consists of a low-protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged. A trial with large doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hour) is also recommended.

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

Inborn Error of Metabolism

Urine Odor

Maple syrup

Hawkinsinuria

Swimming pool

3-Hydroxy-3-methylglutaric aciduria

Cat urine

Sweaty feet

Hypermethioninemia

Tyrosinemia

Tomcat urine

Phenylketonuria

Mousy

Rotting fish
