questions.text: Which of the following hallucinations is more common in a delirious patient?

choices.text: Visions of snakes in the room
Feeling insects crawl over his skin

questions.solution:
Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium.

They range from dream-like experiences to terrifying visions. Other types of hallucination may be present, but are less common.

questions.text: Coma occurs at a glucose level below _____.
questions.solution: Coma occurs when glucose levels fall below 30 mg/dL.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as _______.
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism as the most common enzyme deficiency is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia resembles a male's.

The image below shows ambiguous genitalia in a female with CAH:

The mechanism underlying the endocrine defects in 21-hydroxylase deficiency is depicted in the image below:

Babies with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present around 10-14 days of age with the subset of symptoms due to aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency and androgen excess.

Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises marked by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis.

Cortisol deficiency causes manifestations like hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.

Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency results in virilization of females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency resulting in incomplete virilization. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is 2nd most common enzyme affected in CAH.

Option C: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development(DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

Option D: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency,  17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: What does BNS section 90/IPC Section 314 deal with?

choices.text: Death of mother due to miscarriage
Preventing the child being born alive

questions.solution:
BNS Section 90/IPC Section 314 deals with the death of the mother due to miscarriage.

Important sections of IPC relating to miscarriages:

BNS section

IPC section

Deals with

88

312

Causing miscarriage with consent

89

313

Causing miscarriage without consent

90

314

Death of mother due to miscarriage

91

315

Preventing the child from being born alive or causing it to die after birth

92

316

Causing the death of the quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide

Note: Quick child is a fetus that has developed to such a stage that it moves within the womb of the mother. It shall mean an unborn child whose heart is beating, who is experiencing electronically measurable brain waves, who is discernibly moving, and who is so far developed and matured as to be capable of surviving the trauma of birth with the aid of usual medical care and facilities available in this state.

questions.text: The anaesthesia resident is told to perform the 'spinal of the arm' before an elbow surgery. You observe him as he injects a local anaesthetic at the point shown in the image. What procedure is he performing?
questions.solution:
The procedure being performed is the supraclavicular block. It can be identified by the point of injection 2 cm posterior to the mid-point of clavicle.

The block is given at the level distal to trunks and proximal to divisions of the brachial plexus.  It is also known as the 'spinal of the arm'.

 

It is a type of brachial plexus block used for procedures on the elbow, forearm, and hand. The supraclavicular block does not adequately block the axillary and suprascapular nerves, and thus is not reliable for shoulder surgery.

questions.text: Most important extracellular buffer_____
questions.solution:
The most important extracellular buffer is bicarbonate. The source of bicarbonate is plasma by filteration. It is a non inducible buffer. 

Proteins: Are the most abundant intracellular buffer. 

Phosphate: minor buffer in kidney. The source is plasma by filteration. It is a noninducible buffer. 

Ammonia is a minor buffer, locally produced by tubular cells. Its production increases in metabolic acidosis. It is the only inducible buffer. 

Related Pearl: Principal buffers in the body

Extracellular Buffers Intracellular Buffers Bone Buffers
  • HCO3 (bicarbonate) -Major buffer in ECF and body
  • Plasma proteins
  • Phosphate - minor
  • NH3- minor
  • Organic phosphates [e.g., AMP, ADP, ATP, 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (DPG)]
  • Intracellular proteins
  • Hemoglobin in RBCs

It has been estimated that at least 40% of the buffering of an acute acid load takes place in the bone.

In chronic acidosis continued buffering has adverse effects on bone mineralization and can result in bone diseases such as rickets, osteomalacia, and osteopenia.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as?
questions.solution:
Serotonin is also known as 5 hydroxy-tryptamine, and it is a monoamine neurotransmitter. Serotonin is produced by hydroxylation of tryptophan and subsequent decarboxylation. It is a potent vasoconstrictor and stimulator of smooth muscle contraction.

Clinical correlation:

In carcinoid syndrome, excessive levels of serotonin is produced which causes flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, damage to the tricuspid valve, etc. The levels of 5-OH indole acetic acid (serotonin metabolite) is elevated in the urine.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are lost. This causes urethrocele.

DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome?
questions.solution:
Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is an autosomal recessive disorder.

IGS occurs due to mutations in either the cubulin (CUBN) or amnionless (AMN) genes. They form the cubam receptor responsible for the absorption of the Cbl-IF complex. Hence, this condition leads to congenital cobalamin malabsorption. It is the most common cause of megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency in infancy in Western countries.

Affected children present with lethargy, failure to thrive, and neurological symptoms like hypotonia, developmental delay, and movement disorders. Non-specific proteinuria with normal renal function is seen in 90% of patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the ER with complaints of chest pain. He suddenly collapsed and became unresponsive. His pulse was not recordable so you started chest compressions. Which of the following steps would you not perform according to the BLS algorithm?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal mask airway and other supraglottic airway devices are part of advanced airway management, which is included in advanced cardiac life support (ACLS).

Basic life support refers to the emergency management of sudden cardiac arrest, heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction, usually without the use of equipment other than automated external defibrillators.

The CPR sequence is as follows - circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing:

  • Circulation:
    • Chest compressions lead to ejection of blood from the heart, as a result of actual compression of the heart between the sternum and vertebral column.
  • Airway:
    • Head tilt, chin lift, and jaw thrust maneuvers are used to open the airway.
  • Breathing:
    • If there is no adequate breathing even after opening the airway, the rescuer should initiate assisted ventilation by giving rescue breaths to the patient using mouth-to-mouth, mouth-to-nose, mouth-to-stoma, mouth-to-barrier device, mouth-to-face shield, or mouth-to-mask rescue breathing or by using a bag-mask device.
  • Defibrillation:
    • Using automated external defibrillators (AED)

questions.text: A 34-year-old man sustains facial burns and is being planned for reconstruction with a skin graft. Which type of graft should he receive to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and minimal contraction?
questions.solution:
The patient should receive a Wolfe graft to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and minimal contraction. Wolfe grafts are full-thickness skin grafts that are used for small areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin that will not contract is required (such as fingers, eyelids, and facial parts).

  Full-thickness skin graft (Wolfe) Split thickness skin graft (Thiersche)
Structure Epidermis + complete dermis ± fat Epidermis + part of dermis
Donor site location Post auricular, supra/infra-clavicular. 
Never axillary		 Thigh > buttocks
Donor site wound Must be sutured Requires only dressing and can be reused
Recipient site Must be well vascularised. Small area May be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)
Graft features
Durability High Low
Contracture Primary > secondary High secondary contracture
Uptake Require more care to ensure uptake High-reliability
Cosmetic result Good Poor (abnormal pigmentation)

Option B: Partial-thickness skin grafts or split-thickness grafts are called Thiersch grafts. They consist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. They tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and result in suboptimal cosmetic appearance.

Option C: Composite grafts are grafts that contain skin and fat or skin and cartilage. They are often taken from the ear margin and useful for rebuilding missing elements of the nose, eyelids, and fingertips.

Option D: Blair-Brown grafts are a type of intermediate thickness split skin graft.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing focal foveal detachment.

There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment.

Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central serous choriopathy (CSC).

If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen.

Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are contraindicated.

questions.text: Echocardiography in a patient with pulmonary embolism revealed akinesia of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion at the right ventricular apex. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The sign described is called McConnell’s sign.

It demonstrates right ventricular dysfunction as akinesia of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion at the right ventricular apex. It is the best-known indirect sign of pulmonary embolism on transthoracic echocardiography. 

Moses' (Bancroft's), Homan’s, and Lowenberg’s signs are seen in venous thrombosis. They're not specific to pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Signs related to venous thrombosis

Sign

 Description

Moses’

sign 

 Clinical sign found in patients with deep vein thrombosis of the lower leg involving the posterior tibial veins. The sign is positive if pain is elicited when the calf muscle is compressed forwards against the tibia, but not when the calf muscle is compressed from side to side. 

Homan’s

sign  

 Another clinical sign found in patients with deep vein thrombosis. It is the discomfort behind the knee on forced dorsiflexion of the foot.

Lowenberg’s

sign 

 Clinical sign found in patients with deep vein thrombosis of the lower leg. The sign is positive when pain is elicited rapidly when a blood pressure cuff is placed around the calf and inflated to 80 mmHg.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought with a cough and difficulty in breathing. The baby was admitted with similar complaints in the past. On auscultation, coarse crepitations were heard. Quantitative serum immunoglobulin analysis was done and serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levels were low. His cellular immunity was found to be normal. Which of the following is false about his condition?

choices.text: Germinal centres of lymph nodes are underdeveloped
Manifestation is seen usually after 6 months of age

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bruton agammaglobulinemia/ X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA). Even though it is an immunodeficiency disease, it is paradoxically associated with autoimmune diseases such as arthritis and dermatomyositis in 35% of individuals.

The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics:

  • B cells are absent or markedly decreased and the serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins are decreased
  • T-cell mediated reactions are normal
  • Germinal centers of lymph nodes, Peyer’s patches, the appendix, and tonsils are underdeveloped
  • Plasma cells are absent throughout the body

XLA is characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B cells and pre-B cells) to develop into mature B cells. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk).

The related gene is located on the long arm of the X chromosome. This X-linked disease is seen almost entirely in males. The disease usually does not become apparent until about 6 months of age, when maternal immunoglobulins are depleted.

Affected individuals are susceptible to infections with:

  • Bacteria that are normally opsonized by antibodies and cleared by phagocytosis
    • Haemophilus influenzae
    • Streptococcus pneumonia
    • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Giardia lamblia - intestinal protozoan that is normally resisted by secreted IgA, causes persistent infections 
  • Enteroviruses
    • Echovirus
    • Poliovirus
    • Coxsackievirus

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: On which of the following chromosomes is the BRCA2 gene located?
questions.solution:
BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q12.3). 

Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are responsible for 80 to 90% of single gene familial breast cancers and about 3% of all breast cancers.

ER-positive, HER2-negative cancers (luminal type) is the most common subtype of breast cancer in individuals who inherit germline mutations in BRCA2. This gene is associated more frequently with male breast cancer.

Single gene mutations associated with familial breast cancer can be categorized into:

  • High penetrance germline mutations (>4 fold increased risk) - BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, STK11, CDH I, PALPB2
  • Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2-4 fold increased risk) - ATM, CHEK2

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated

questions.text: A tribal farmer, presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed on examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis of pinguecula. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains.

Pinguecula has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in almost all by 80 years of age.

Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the trauma unit following a road traffic accident. He is hemodynamically unstable. As an adjunct to the primary survey, the managing surgeon decides to do a FAST. Which of the following areas would not be visualized in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The left lower quadrant is not assessed in FAST examination.

FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries.

FAST also stands for Focussed abdominal sonography for trauma. However, since FAST is not only used to assess abdominal injuries but also to assess haemopericardium in cases of pericardial injuries, the expansion Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma is preferred. It can be performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique of FAST examination:

With the patient in the supine position, a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used.

Four regions may be scanned:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view - To assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
  • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant - To assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morrison's pouch.
  • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant - To assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region - To assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.

In an extended FAST or eFAST scan, left and right thoracic views are used to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

questions.text: A patient presented with an abscess on his back. Septic precautions were taken and the abscess was drained. On follow up, a healthy scar was visible. What is the type of collagen seen in the provisional matrix in this type of healing?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of wound healing by secondary intention. The initial provisional matrix in this type of healing is composed of type III collagen, fibrin, and plasma fibronectin.

It is later replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen.

This type of healing occurs when cell or tissue loss is more extensive, such as in large wounds, abscesses, ulceration, and ischemic necrosis in parenchymal organs. The repair process involves a combination of regeneration and scarring.

questions.text: A patient with cystic fibrosis was found to be underweight during his regular check-up. He complains of low appetite and you decide to prescribe an appetite-stimulating agent. Which antihistaminic drug can you prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine has an appetite-stimulating effect and has been used to promote weight gain in poor eaters.

The appetite-stimulating effect may be due to the H1 antihistaminic effect and an effect on growth hormone secretion.

questions.text: While writing your medical competitive exams, you come across the following image of karyotyping analysis in a question. You recognize this image as being highly suggestive of a particular syndrome.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above karyotype is suggestive of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

Clinical features of Trisomy 13/Patau syndrome (Mnemonic CMC DOCToR OPD)

  • Cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect/atrial septal defect/patent ductus arteriosus)
  • Microcephaly, Microphthalmia
  • Cleft lip/palate
  • Developmental delay
  • Ocular hypotelorism
  • Holoprosencephaly
  • Thin posterior ribs (missing ribs)
  • Renal abnormalities
  • Polydactyly with flexed fingers
  • Polycystic kidneys
  • Scalp defects (aplasia cutis)

Image: 37-week male with Patau syndrome demonstrating alobar holoprosencephaly with cyclopia. Facial features included a sloping forehead with a nose superior to a single central palpebral fissure.

questions.text: A vascular surgeon is operating on a case of aortic dissection of the thoracic aorta. He suspects that the dissection has extended into the abdominal aorta, and approaches the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm to localize the extension. Which of the following structures will be present here?

choices.text: Left gastric vein and thoracic duct
Right vagus nerve and thoracic duct
Left vagus nerve and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
The azygous vein and the thoracic duct are present at the aortic hiatus. These are transmitted along with the thoracic aorta. 

Clinical significance:

Aortic dissection occurs when there's an intimal tear in the aorta. It presents with tearing interscapular pain and extension of dissection into the abdominal aorta can present with abdominal pain. CT/MRI are the investigations of choice. Aortic dissections are classified using the DeBakey and Stanford systems. Depending on the classification, aortic dissections are managed with aggressive antihypertensive therapy or immediate surgical intervention (open/endovascular).

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.
